—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Given the critical role of shipping in improving Australia's export performance and hence in creating jobs and economic growth, what initiatives has the Government taken to improve Australia's overseas commercial shipping arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. It is a fact that the adequacy and efficiency of shipping arrangements are vital to the performance of Australia's economy. It is also true that Australia's export performance is vital to development, the creation of growth and job creation. A study done recently by the Department of Trade has shown that a 5 per cent growth in export income would result in the creation of an initial 30,000 jobs. Our shipping policy has been dedicated to improving the efficiency and the competitiveness of Australian shipping. Our aim is to provide an efficient service for exporters and importers. So often in consideration of this issue the needs of importers have been overlooked, particularly in relation to freight rates. We need to ensure that regulation assists effective development of the shipping industry and industry generally. We need to develop a commercially sound Australian flag fleet, a fleet that is efficient and competitive in world markets. Whether the ships are Australian controlled or overseas controlled, the important thing is that they be efficient and that the services are adequate for our needs.

ANSWER.PARA: The existing regulatory framework for overseas commercial shipping was developed by the conservative Government in the mid-1960s. Essentially, that same system operates today. I need to say that there have been many changes to needs since then. There have been changes to the nature of the products for shipping and changes in markets. There are questions among the users of shipping services as to whether, for instance, we should have a pan-Australia rate-a single, national Australia rate-irrespective of the port of collection, as long as products are going to the same destination. That is an issue about which the industries concerned have differing views. Some believe that the situation should be changed. Some believe that it should remain as it is. There are questions as to whether importers are, in fact, cross-subsidising exporters by way of freight rates, given the imbalance of trade that occurs in both directions. There are questions as to whether the liner conference arrangements are suitable, whether they are appropriate in today's conditions. In more recent years we have seen the inroads of non-conference shipping into those areas. Other questions that affect our primary industries are raised in relation to loyalty agreements and secret rebates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you are going to do.

—If the honourable member is not concerned about the problems he is just maintaining the record of his predecessors. They were very good at ignoring the needs of shipping in this country and the implications of shipping services, particularly for our primary industries. If the honourable member maintains the record of his predecessors he will do well!
—Order! I invite the Minister to return to the answer to the question.
—We need also to--
—Tell us what you are going to do.
—Order! I also invite the honourable member for O'Connor to cease his usual 2 o'clock and after chatter.
—The honourable member may be concerned more with land leases and rental arrangements than with shipping needs, Mr Speaker.
—Order! I have invited the Minister to ignore the interjections.

—I accept your advice, Mr Speaker. Other issues involved are the roles of national flag shipping and non-conference operators, and how they fit into the arrangements we have. Essentially, we have a multitude of users who have differing priorities and views which are often in conflict. Out of all of that mess some resolution has to be made to ensure that we get the best mix of services. This Government has given priority to the development of our shipping needs, recognising their importance, as I said earlier, to industry. In order to facilitate industry debate and user views being put forward, I established a complete review of overseas commercial shipping arrangements in September last year. That review is to report by July this year. Its recommendations are to be incorporated in a draft policy paper to be circulated for public comment. It is our intention that there be full consultation with all interested parties and, if legislation is to arise from it, the approximate timetable is that it will come forward in the autumn sittings of Parliament next year. Let me summarise. Unlike the Liberal--

For the benefit of the right honourable member for New England, I quote from the December edition of Maritime Asia.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Have there been requests from the Queensland and New South Wales governments for the immigration entry of power workers and doctors respectively? If so, has there been any difference in the response to each of these governments by the Commonwealth Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can tell the honourable member for Rankin that there has been an approach from Queensland; but, so far as I am aware, there has been no approach from New South Wales. I am aware that the Premier of New South Wales suggested, after certain processes had been followed, that he may make such an inquiry; but I repeat that, so far as I am aware, no such approach has been made. I can assure the House that if and when that approach is made, it will be treated in exactly the same way as the approach from the Premier and the Government of Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: The guidelines are long-standing and the House is entitled to know what they are. Any government can make a group nomination for a class of workers that it wants under what is known as the employer nomination scheme. Once that group nomination is made, there are certain labour market tests that need to be carried out. Those tests are carried out for me-the buck eventually stops with me-by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and cover such matters as, firstly, whether people are available in the particular skills that are required; secondly, whether those skills that are alleged to be needed are proper for the particular jobs; and thirdly, whether there are industrial relations implications in the particular nominations. Some spokesman for the Opposition has suggested that we were promising some fast track for one particular inquiry and a slow track for another. There is no substance whatsoever to such a charge. These tests take time but we can get them covered in three to six months, not the two to three years suggested by that Opposition spokesman.

I return to the approach from Queensland. It was in two forms. There was a telex from the Premier to the Prime Minister and there was also an unofficial approach on the part of officials of the Queensland Government to officials of my Department in my regional office in Brisbane. In both cases insufficient information was given initially for us to be able to go through those labour market tests. That information was sought and we then learnt the nature of the particular inquiry in terms which were necessary for us to carry out the tests. Once that information had been received from Queensland, we learnt that Queensland workers were and are available for the particular jobs for which workers were being sought. There were and are plenty of workers in Queensland who are willing to work under the terms laid down by the Industrial Commission in Queensland. I cannot say anything about New South Wales because we have not yet had such an inquiry from that State. In conclusion, I can tell the House that for the next 10, 15 or more years the Australian Labor Party will govern this country, and it shall administer the guidelines for this test, as for other immigration tests, without fear and without favour.

—I ask the Minister for Housing and Construction: Are the housing policies of the Victorian Government and the Victorian Opposition in accordance with the provisions of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am pleased to say that the Victorian Government's housing policy is quite consistent with the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement; but I regret to say that a key element of the Victorian Opposition's housing policy directly contravenes the Commonwealth- State Housing Agreement. I refer to its proposal to sell off public housing rental stock at a discount. It proposes a one per cent discount for each year of tenancy. The potential here is to be selling off rental stock at a 20, 30 or 35 per cent discount. This proposal is in clear breach of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. One could even suggest that this element of the Victorian Opposition housing policy is not lawful. Section 34 of the Agreement says that all sales of housing shall be at market value or replacement cost at the time of sale. Certainly, credits can be allowed for home improvements, but there is no provision for a set formula of discounting. The Agreement goes on to stipulate that finance derived from sales should be used for the replacement of rental stock. The object of this element of the agreement is to increase, not decrease, rental stocks of housing.

ANSWER.PARA: What the Victorian Opposition proposes is, in fact, a form of asset stripping of the housing assets of the Victorian Ministry of Housing. I know that one could expect this from people with the competence of the Victorian Opposition but, on the other hand, the Victorian Government is this year spending a record $291m on public housing, $190m of it going to the rental program, $79m for home purchase assistance, and $22m for assistance to disadvantaged groups. I might add that $148m of this money comes from the Hawke Federal Labor Government through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. The Hawke Labor Government is also contributing so far $82m to 28,000 Victorian households through the spectacularly successful first home ownership scheme. I conclude by saying that I am really very sorry that the Victorian Opposition has not had the foresight to examine the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement before formulating its housing policy. I would have thought that this was an essential prerequisite to the formulation of a responsible housing policy, but instead all it has tried to do is mislead the voters of Victoria.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer the honourable gentleman to Australia's huge current account and trade deficits. Now that the Prime Minister has effectively ruled out any discounting of national wage adjustments for the effects of the recent depreciation of the Australian dollar, thus throwing away any competitive gain conferred upon our export and import competing industries by that depreciation, what steps does the Government propose to take to improve the competitive position of those industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the honourable member would hang his head in shame when we talked about competitiveness in any circumstances, because he gave us a 12 per cent inflation rate while the rest of the world with which we were trading had a rate of around 6 per cent. I thought he would be the last person to ask me a question about competitiveness. It amuses me that in the honourable gentleman's question there is a presumption about the impact on wages if indeed there is over the medium term a depreciation effect against a whole gaggle of currencies. His question is based on the assumption that, under his policies in his time, there would have been no increase in wages for the 12 months between April 1984 and April 1985. He is cavilling at the potential for some wage flow on through the indexation system as though conditions would have been now as they might have been under his policies. In fact, under his policies we would already have had the wage increases. Under his policies we would not be worrying about any future wage increases coming as a result of the depreciation; we would already have had them. Having presided over a wage explosion in 1981, how can he argue that through the strong growth of 1983-84 and 1984-85 he could have had two back to back years of wage restraint like we have had in this country? Until the wage adjustment of April 1985 in this year's national wage case there will have been no movement in award wages since April 1984, and that in a period of very strong economic growth. The former Treasurer could not have delivered that. That was delivered as a result of this Government's policies. We would already have had under the previous Government the wage increase about which the honourable member is now worried. Our competitiveness would have been further eroded because he would have been at this stage, as he advocates, applying a credit squeeze to the economy to try to choke inflation by choking growth. He would be back to his old policies. As he says every day on the radio and in his Press statements, he would be tightening up credit, having a credit squeeze to squeeze inflation out of the economy, thus killing growth. Let us not have any nonsense about the erosion of competitiveness; we would be out the door already in regard to wages and the recovery under Opposition policies.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason for the current account deficit is the lagged effect of Australia's competitiveness, which this Government has only just restored. This Government has only just restored Australia's competitive position in terms of a decline in inflation and any problems in the current account reflect two factors-the snap back of imports in the recovery and the demand coming off the recovery for imports, acting on the current account, with the lagged effect of the wage explosion induced by the Leader of the Opposition when he was Minister for Industrial Relations and by the former Treasurer. If this country has any problems in terms of competitiveness, honourable members opposite are to blame for it. This Government has brought inflation back to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of around 5 per cent. Honourable members opposite should not worry about competitiveness as we have it well and truly in hand. Their policies already would be eroding the competitiveness which this Government has been able to secure through the prices and incomes accord.

I wish to make two further comments about this so-called concern of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Obviously there has been no inflationary impact at this time from the devaluation. It depends upon what happens to the Australian dollar against a trade weight of currencies over time and in the medium term. The next national wage case is six months away. We will think about it in the mean time. Only 15 per cent of our demand is satisfied by imports. If we look at the 17 per cent depreciation figure under the former Government we will see that the inflationary impact was very muted indeed because it came through lagged and in dribs and drabs. At this stage nobody can say what the inflationary impact would be, even if the current exchange rate relationships applied. Honourable members opposite should not worry about it; we will look after Australia. They could not.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. What action is being taken to analyse the informal vote at the last Federal election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, as all honourable members know, that we did have an exceedingly high informal vote at the 1984 House of Representatives election. Prior to the election the Australian Electoral Commission did a number of surveys of the electorate as to people's understanding of the new voting system for the Senate. From results the Commission was getting from that research it was obvious that very few people, less than 5 per cent in fact just a few months before the election, understood the new system that had been put in place by this Parliament acting on the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform in that we could have a list system of voting for the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: The Electoral Commission persuaded the Government that resources ought to be given to it to be able to publicise, in all forms of media, the new system that was to apply at the 1984 election for the voting for the Senate. It was unfortunate that in doing so-I do not think that anybody has laid claim to the fact that he might have been wiser then than he is now-it was overlooked that this might have some impact on how people voted for the House of Representatives, in respect of which the Joint Committee and indeed the Parliament had made no change at all.

The fact is that there were 625,000 informal votes for the House of Representatives in 1984 compared with 185,000 in 1983. For the Senate the campaign worked very successfully. In 1983 there were 872,000 informal votes, which I think all of us would agree is a disgrace to the system. In 1984 that figure had been reduced by half-to 440,000 informal votes for the Senate-which was the objective of this Parliament in changing the system. I think it was a very wise course to adopt. There was also a very disturbing feature about the referendums, in that the informal vote was also over 400,000 on the simultaneous elections question and 600,000 on the interchange of powers question.

The Australian Electoral Commission is currently carrying out a comprehensive survey of all the informal papers, the results of which will be known to us next month. The survey will make known to us practically all the information in relation to the Parliament that surrounds the reason why people may have voted informally. There have been lots of theories, but some of those theories have already been somewhat exploded--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are worried about this now only after you have the redistribution through.

—The honourable member ought to be careful because I think there might be a big bonus in this informal vote for us in the next election. He had better have a close look. I advise him to just be very patient.
—How is Andrew going to look then?

—The honourable member does not have to worry about Andrew because the honourable member for Bennelong is not playing trivial pursuits; he is after Andrew's job. When the results of the Commission's survey are known, not only will they be up for discussion within the Parliament, but also obviously the Government would want to refer them to the Joint Committee. Any recommendations the Joint Committee has in order that we may be able to improve the system even further would be looked on favourably by the Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. What progress has been made in respect of the May Committee of Inquiry into the National Road Freight Industry recommendations following its inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Honourable members will recall that the May Committee was appointed in July 1983 to carry out the first ever comprehensive analysis and examination of the national road freight industry and it reported towards the latter part of last year. The recommendations of the inquiry headed by Tom May aimed particularly at introducing economic stability into the industry. The inquiry came down very strongly against an argument of government regulation on entry into the industry and freight rate setting. In that inquiry the question of industrial representation for owner-drivers was raised. The view of the inquiry was that that matter would be better dealt with by the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. I understand that that report will be submitted to my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations at the end of next month.

ANSWER.PARA: The package of recommendations brought forward by Tom May and his colleagues put forward to be accepted as a package in principle. The recommendations aimed at improving truck safety, improving conditions of operation within the industry. It was recommended that operator licensing be introduced so that there would be protection for drivers who may be involved in breaches of the law brought about by economic pressures and tasks which they were required to do by prime contractors. The recommendations also included provision for better training of drivers first entering the industry. That package of 98 recommendations has been accepted in principle by the State and Territory Ministers for Transport. Those recommendations are under consideration by the Government and I hope to be able to make an announcement in the near future as to the outcome.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.

4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The growing doubts about the Government's ability and resolve to effectively manage the economy as exemplified by the recent depreciation of the Australian dollar.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The economic news-indeed, most of the news-of the nation over the last couple of weeks has been dominated by the fall in the value of the Australian dollar. There can be no doubt that the fall in the value of the Australian dollar which has been recorded over the last several weeks is in part-I stress in part-a direct result of a fall in the level of confidence in the economic management and resolve of the Hawke Government. That decline has taken place not only domestically but also internationally. If we wanted any evidence of why people overseas are now having real doubts as to whether what they previously perceived to be relatively responsible economic policies pursued by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) any longer prevail, we found a very good reason for those doubts in Question Time yesterday and Question Time again today.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday, in answer to a question I put to the Prime Minister, he got up and-I paraphrase the answer he gave-said: 'I agree with you that the economically sensible and rational thing to do is to discount the next national wage case for the effects of the devaluation on the consumer price index. That is the economically responsible thing to do, but I cannot do it because I am bound by the terms of the prices and incomes accord'. That is what the Prime Minister was saying yesterday. He was, in effect, giving official ratification and confirmation to the view that buying industrial peace is more important than the longer term economic health of Australia and is more important than the impact on the unemployed of Australia of a wage determination system that increasingly this country cannot afford.

As the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) acknowledged yesterday, the depreciation of the Australian dollar of recent weeks, despite the adverse effects of it and despite the fact that it represents some failure or loss of confidence by others in the policies and the assets of this country, confers some competitive gain and edge on our export and import competing industries. The Prime Minister did not dissent from that point of view. However, the important thing is that, if we are not to suffer all the disadvantages of a depreciation of our currency, we must be willing to insulate our import competing and export industries from the adverse price effects of that depreciation. The only way we can do that is by insulating those industries through the wages system. Increasingly, what is happening, of course, is that the floating of the Australian dollar has imposed strains upon our wage fixation system and has demonstrated how inappropriate our wage determination system is.

Instead of standing up yesterday and saying to the Australian public that the Government would be willing to discount for the effects of the depreciation of the Australian dollar, the Prime Minister rather supinely threw up his arms and said: 'I would like to do it. I know it is the economically responsible thing to do, but I cannot do it because it would break the prices and incomes accord'. What he was doing, as he did over the MX missile issue, was saying that when it comes to a choice between numbers and duty he will choose numbers any time. He has demonstrated that time and again. He demonstrated it over his failure to dismiss the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) from the Cabinet on two occasions; he demonstrated it over the MX missile issue and he is demonstrating it again by his failure to follow the only economically rational course in the wake of the depreciation of the Australian dollar. What the Prime Minister knows in his heart and what proper observers of the Australian economic scene know is a reality, and it is a reality that I pointed out in December 1983 when the Government floated the Australian dollar, a decision that I warmly welcomed then and still welcome as one of the very good and praiseworthy decisions that the Hawke Government has taken. I said on that occasion:

Now that the dollar has, quite properly, been floated, the Government can no longer 'fudge' the exchange rate in order to protect it from the consequences of inappropriate and irresponsible domestic fiscal, monetary and wages policies. The dollar float imposes a new discipline on the Government. There is little prospect that the industrial wing of the labour movement and the left-wing of the Labor Party will respond to that discipline.

If ever we had a demonstration that the Government would not respond to that discipline, we had it yesterday when the Prime Minister was unwilling to give the only economically responsible answer to the question that I asked. It is no wonder that this morning the Australian Chamber of Commerce, one of the largest business organisations in Australia, had this to say:

The business community views with complete bewilderment the Prime Minister's statement that the Federal Government would support the passing on to wages of the inflationary effects of the recent decline in the Australian dollar. The statement will only serve to undermine the value of earlier statements by other senior Cabinet Ministers and by the Prime Minister himself on the need to engender business confidence.

That is not a bad smack in the eye from the President of the Australian Chamber of Commerce. It is no wonder, because it is an example of the declining domestic confidence in the economic policies of this Government.

I have said repeatedly over the past several weeks that there are external reasons for the decline in the value of the dollar. It is not the fault of the present Government or, indeed, any Australian government that these have occurred. I refer, of course, to the strength of the United States dollar and the fact that as a commodity trader we, in common with all other commodity traders, have seen our currency depreciate because of the depressed level of commodity prices. But there one must end the exculpation of the present Government because when one moves to the other set of reasons, one finds that this Government is very much to blame. I and other Opposition members have said repeatedly over the past couple of weeks that the humiliating retreat of the Prime Minister over the MX missile issue has broken in a very significant way the confidence that many people had in him in the economic area. I was told repeatedly by people in the financial community in the United States when I followed the Prime Minister's visit there a couple of weeks ago: 'If he backed down to the left wing in this issue, he will back down to the left wing on other issues'.

The decline in the value of the Australian dollar represents a vote of loss of confidence in the leadership of the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and this Government. There is no way that the Government can wriggle and worm out of that because a floating exchange rate tells the story and tells it quickly, plainly and without any kind of fear or favour. That is what makes a floating exchange rate a far better method of running one's exchange rate than other systems. That is why a floating exchange rate continues to have the support of the Opposition and, to his credit, the support of the Treasurer. No doubt he hopes that somehow or other, the realism that a floating exchange rate brings home, will make some of his colleagues aware of many of the difficulties.

This loss of confidence in the economic policies of the Government is not something that has arisen only over the last couple of weeks as exemplified by the fall in value of the Australian dollar. One can go back to the Budget of last year. If ever there was an election Budget, if ever there was a Budget designed purely and simply for the polls and not for the medium or the longer term, it was the 1984 Budget. It was a Budget that I described at the time as 'a political document, based on the vote now, pay later principle'. That Budget maximised short term electoral possibilities, but I warned at the time that next year it would present major economic problems on the budgetary front. Of course, those major problems are now becoming apparent. Even in areas where the Government was able in its early months of office to point to some level of success, a slow down is starting to occur. This is happening, for example, in the employment area. Remember how much we were regaled by the Government about the improvements in employment that had taken place since it was elected? Total employment, seasonally adjusted, grew by 3.1 per cent in the 12 months to March 1984, but in the 10 months to January 1984 it has increased at an annual rate of only 1.6 per cent. Real interest rates-that is, the gap between the nominal rate and the rate of inflation-are now the highest that they have been for two generations. This Treasurer not only presided over the highest tax take in Australia's history in the last Budget and the highest level of expenditure in Australia's history in the last Budget, but he also now presides over the highest real interest rates that this country has seen since the end of World War II. No wonder people here and overseas are starting to vote a lack of confidence.

Of course, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister are not alone. It amuses me no end to see Labor premiers running around the world inviting foreign banks to establish headquarters in their particular cities. Who else could I think of this week but the Victorian Premier, Mr Cain, who has not been slow to run around the world inviting this and that bank to establish its headquarters in Melbourne and to a parade all the marvellous advantages of having the headquarters of a bank in Melbourne. There is absolutely nothing wrong with having the headquarters of one's bank in Melbourne. Melbourne is a terrific city. The only thing wrong with it at the moment is its State Government. If ever a person were aligned, in terms of policy attitudes, to those policies of the Federal Government which are now losing favour internationally, it is the Premier of Victoria. Not only has he a sorry record of increases in taxes and charges and of mortgaging the future assets of Victoria's instrumentalities to an unconscionable extent to overseas lenders, but to the Victorian Premier belongs the dubious distinction of being the first political figure in office in the Western world to say that facilities for nuclear-powered vessels would not be available in his port. The Victorian Premier was even two years ahead of the New Zealand Prime Minister in saying that visits by nuclear-powered warships would not be welcome in Victorian ports. I quote from his remarkable statement in 1982, when he declared:
. . . visits by nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed warships to Victoria from any country are not welcome.

Everybody remembers that, fortunately, that exercise in anti-Americanism by the present Victorian Premier was very smartly put down by the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser. It is very interesting that as far as Mr Cain's ideology and his attitudes are concerned, he was even two years ahead of the New Zealand Prime Minister. That gives us an idea of the nature, the calibre and the quality of the leadership of that Government.

I realise, Madam Deputy Speaker, that I digress a little from my comments on the management of the national economy, but the point must still be made that the economic policies that I condemn, the economic policies that have eroded international confidence in the Australian dollar, are fully supported by that same Premier who led the break out at the 1983 Premiers Conference, where at the last minute the Treasurer got rolled and had to give another $400m in funds to the States.

The last two weeks has seen the coming together of various strands which indicate a loss of confidence in the economic management of this Government. It faces an horrendous problem on the wages front. Not only has it a wage indexation system that this country cannot afford, but the secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions has said that this country has the most beneficial wage fixation system for the trade union movement of any country in the world. On the wages front, the Government also faces the difficulty of what to do with the productivity case. It faces the problem of putting together a Budget in 1985 when it will have to pay the price of its electoral vote-buying Budget of 1984 and in many other areas it faces an erosion of the international competitiveness of Australian industry. Most importantly, it faces a Prime Minister who no longer has the authority and respect that people previously believed he enjoyed.

Opposition members could not keep a fiscal policy together if they tried, yet they are trying to tell us that there is something wrong with our Budgets. They should just pick up the newspapers and look at the restoration of profits across companies. Do honourable members opposite really think anyone in Australian business seriously believes that the Liberal Party of Australia has any policies to give non-inflationary growth to this country? No one in business does. The business community has given members of the Liberal Party up. It has sold them out because they are not worth supporting. They have no ideas. TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously monitor it fairly closely.

The fact of the matter is that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the great monetarist, the man who believes in monetary targets, never hit a monetary target once in five years as Treasurer. That is the first thing. The second thing is that this Government brought the money supply on target in 1983-84, despite $4 billion of capital inflow. We were issuing bonds as if they were going out of style through 1983-84 to get to that monetary target. Even though we have an incomes policy in place we do not accept the view that we do not have to worry about monetary policy, that monetary policy can just be lax and that money can swim around. We do not accept either the religious relationship between the precise increase in monetary growth and inflation. We fixed upon a neutral monetary policy, a neutral firm monetary stance throughout 1983-84, and we are prepared to do the same thing in 1984-85. When the Budget came down in 1984-85 we said that we would look to adjustments for growth and if there was more growth mid-year than we thought, we would adjust the target up for growth and we would adjust it for re-intermediation. But what we did not know and did not say, because we were not aware of it at the time, is that not only have we had re-intermediation but also we have had intermediation. In other words, there is now much more activity in the financial sector in terms of the reflection of monetary growth relative to a given level of activity in the economy. The relationships between the monetary aggregates and gross domestic product have changed as they have changed in the United States of America. When Paul Volcker announced shifts in monetary policy three years ago he copped the same sort of nonsense that I have copped from the Opposition as a result.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that this Government is not abandoning monetary policy. We are prosecuting a firm monetary policy but we have set aside the target in this period of uncertainty because M3 and the broader M's are no longer a reliable guide to what is happening between monetary activity and activity in the economy. TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance submitted by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is in the following terms:

They thought members of the Government had Iraqi breakfasts. This was the general image of the Labor Party within the international, business and financial community. The Treasurer had an extremely difficult task in removing this image and, backed up by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), he went round all the board rooms and international conference tables to give a totally different impression of a Labor government. Basically what the Treasurer and the Prime Minister were saying was: 'We are not like Whitlam, Cairns, Khemlani or any of these people. We are sound economic managers. We have got the lunatics in our Party under total control. All the left wing fourth graders are people that we can put our finger on. We have also got Labor governments in the various States, which are perfectly sensible, run by commonsense business type gentlemen who also wear dark suits and ties on public occasions. Nonetheless, he committed himself and that commitment to this trilogy has been noted by local and international communities. I remind the House that the trilogy is not to increase taxes at a faster rate than the growth in the economy, to reduce Government spending as a proportion of the nation's output and not to increase the Budget deficit as a proportion of the national product. Today in the House the Treasurer has tightened up that third element of that commitment by saying that the deficit will not increase in money terms. That was an important additional tightening of the commitment by the Treasurer in public today.

The hilarity with which members of the Opposition respond to that point convinces me that, despite the fact that I tried to give them credit for understanding what this is all about, they do not. When the previous Government was thrown out of office we inherited an inflation rate of about 10.4 per cent. Opposition members know that the rate was at least twice the inflation rate of our competitors among the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. As a result of that high inflation rate, the domestic value of the Australian currency fell. But in terms of the exchange rate, it was maintained at that artificially high level internationally. When the exchange rate was free to be determined by market forces, there was then an opportunity for it to reach an appropriate level, and that is exactly what is taking place at present. Incidentally, what we should be doing is not looking at the exchange rate of the Australian currency in relation to the American dollar; we should be looking at a more appropriate measure of our currency, such as the trade weighted index.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still down.

—Yes, but it is not down to the same extent. I emphasise again that we are seeing the final shakeout in the value of the Australian currency. There are definite advantages in the exchange rate of the Australian dollar reaching its appropriate market level. It is doing that at present. I would like to see less volatility in it but, quite clearly--

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 February, on motion by Ms Jakobsen:
That the following Address-in-Reply to the Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General be agreed to:
May it please Your Excellency:

We, the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Macarthur, I remind the House that this is a maiden speech and I ask the House to extend the usual courtesies to the honourable member.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially, Madam Deputy Speaker, I congratulate you on your election as Chairman of Committees. I certainly look forward to serving under your astute guidance during the life of this Parliament. I would like you to convey my similar congratulations to Mr Speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak for the first time in this House with a very acute sense of honour and responsibility which the electors of Macarthur have entrusted to me. It is somewhat remarkable that, during the life of this Parliament, no fewer than three former members for Macarthur, plus me, will share this building. The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) ably represented the people of Macarthur between 1972 and 1975. His performance within the Ministry has brought high critical acclaim from his former constituents and the Australian people at large. Having failed last year to gain his own Party's preselection for a seat in the New South Wales Parliament, Mr Michael Baume will join the Opposition ranks in the Senate in July. My immediate predecessor and good friend, Mr Hollis, takes his seat within this House as the honourable member for Throsby.

I believe it is traditional in a maiden speech to extend thanks to many people-to family, friends, political colleagues and so on. I take this opportunity to acknowledge publicly the support I have received from my wife Carol, the rank and file members of the Australian Labor Party in the electorate of Macarthur who selected me to contest the seat for Australia's only true party of social conscience, and, particularly, my very close friend and mentor, the Hon. Laurie Kelly, Speaker of the Legislative Assembly in New South Wales. I also extend sincere appreciation to a former great Australian Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, who, although I only met him, formally, on the opening day of the Parliament, shook from me the shackles of political apathy and steeled my commitment to reform, social justice and equality for all Australians. Finally, and perhaps most importantly, I extend my thanks to the working class people of Macarthur who put me here.

The electorate of Macarthur has emerged from the redistribution as a New South Wales south coast provincial and semi-rural electorate, stretching inland from the northern Wollongong suburbs between Austinmer and Mount Ousley to include the towns of Wilton, Appin, Bargo, Picton, Tahmoor, Camden and Warragamba. As a life-long resident of Wollongong, I can fairly claim to be a son of Illawarra, completely familiar with its people, its problems and its aspirations. As a former high school teacher and university lecturer in Wollongong, a town planner in Campbelltown and an alderman of the Wollongong City Council, I bring to this House an intimate knowledge of the electorate and a desire and commitment to work for its advancement.

I realise that this is no mean task. The once proud Illawarra-Macarthur region, famous world-wide as the cradle of Australia's rural industry, has been ravaged in recent years by twin evils-the effects of a major economic recession and board room decisions of overseas multinational companies and monopolies. Macarthur's recent economic history has been dependent almost totally on the well-being of manufacturing industry and the underground coal mining industry. With the decline of these, the very social and economic fabric of my electorate has undergone considerable change.

Dominant in the manufacturing sector is the steel industry at Port Kembla which, although located in the neighbouring electorate of Cunningham, over many years has provided employment opportunities for the residents of the Macarthur electorate. In 1981 Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd employed almost 20 per cent of the total employee population of the Illawarra region, while a considerable proportion of the remaining employment was found in enterprises directly related to or under the corporate umbrella of the steel industry. The lack of diversity in the regional economy earned Wollongong the title of 'steel city' and meant that the region was particularly vulnerable to the rapid structural change and the recession of the early 1980s.

In the period of post-war industrial expansion the steel industry contributed to large scale employment generation and population growth, with an extremely high proportion of the work force being derived from overseas countries. However, by 1971 the progressive substitution of capital for labour and consequent productivity gains had led to a stabilisation of employment of around 20,000. At this time, through a combination of corporate policy decisions and a belated recognition of the need to rationalise, in my view due largely to poor forward planning and a failure by the company to detect the warning signs that modern overseas steel plants would shortly create massive problems of competition for Australia, unemployment rates in the industry rose dramatically. Employment at the Port Kembla plant fell from 20,368 in 1981 to a current level of around 13,000. In addition, this crisis was amplified by the effect on subsidiary and dependent companies in the Illawarra-Macarthur regions. It is estimated that for each job lost in the steel industry another was lost in the region. While it is not possible to determine precisely the current unemployment rate for the Macarthur electorate, a figure close to 20 per cent, based on data from the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security, is not unrealistic.

However, to its great credit, this Government has responded positively to the crisis in the steel industry-a crisis reflected by international overproduction and the declining domestic demand for steel. In 1983 the steel industry's plan was announced which saw the industry, unions and government agree to a wide range of options to encourage intensive modernisation and rationalisation at the Port Kembla plant and in other steel plants of Australia. Through union agreements on productivity, government agreements on steel import levels, guarantees of percentage shares in the Australian domestic steel market and industry guarantees regarding levels of investment in modernisation and expansion programs, a degree of stability has again been brought back into the industry.

But a word of caution is necessary. Constant surveillance must be kept of changes in domestic and international economic conditions, particularly as reflected by levels of imports. The fact that these import levels have now reached 30 per cent of the local steel market is of major concern to the whole Illawarra community. I am pleased that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is aware of this problem and has indicated that remedial action may be forthcoming. Further, the existing situation with respect to the levels of protection for the steel industries in other countries, particularly the United States of America and New Zealand, must be carefully monitored. The United States has recently limited its imports to 18.5 per cent of its steel needs and has been directly responsible for the excess of steel on the world market.

Problems of negotiating steel agreements with New Zealand, despite the existence of the closer economic relations agreement between Australia and New Zealand, have had similar effects on steel production in Australia. I was pleased to read recently that the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) has made tentative plans to stage a mini-summit with representatives of the New Zealand Government to discuss this issue. Whilst I applaud this initiative, I believe care must be taken to ensure that imports of New Zealand steel into Australia do not impinge upon the viability of the Australian steel industry.

The problems of the manufacturing sector alone have not been responsible for the economic ills of the Macarthur electorate. It is fair to say that in recent years no sector of my electorate has been more devastated than the coal industry. There are no fewer than 17 underground mines within the boundaries of Macarthur and nearly 90 per cent of the electorate is underlain with black gold. Mining giants such as BP Australia Ltd, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd are all operative in the area, providing principally coking coal and some steaming coal for domestic and export markets. Since 1982 there have been massive retrenchments in the coal industry and a number of pits have been closed or rationalised. Unfortunately for my electorate, most retrenchments in New South Wales have taken place in the southern coalfields. Over 2,000 jobs have been lost in this area alone.

The effect of those sackings on the mines and the community of the Illawarra and the Burragorang Valley and such towns as Camden, Picton and Tahmoor, has been nothing short of horrendous. Indeed, had it not been for the combined efforts of this Government, the Labor Government of New South Wales and the mining unions, many hundreds more miners would have been subjected to the same fate and other collieries would have been closed in the name of economic rationalisation. Yet within the industry it is now believed that underground mining has a brighter future in the long term, particularly in respect of open cut operations in New South Wales and Queensland. As well, latest production figures would seem to indicate that underground mining produces coal more cheaply. If this is the case, why is the industry of the south coast and the Burragorang Valley plagued by shutdowns and retrenchments? Optimism expressed within the industry must be tempered with a realisation that, both for the present and for the foreseeable future, companies must compete against each other for prized international markets in an economic climate of massive oversupply. With more than 20 million tonnes of hard coking coal stockpiled around the world, international coal contracts are being awarded only to the most efficient producers, or to those companies prepared to undercut prices offered by competitors.

A major technical problem threatening the coal industry in the Macarthur area concerns the question of transportation. The construction of stage 1 of the Port Kembla coal loader has provided export facilities for hard coking coal, transported to the loader by rail and road. New South Wales State Government policy dictates that in most cases rail transport of coal must be used. The Maldon-Dombarton rail line under construction promises to alleviate some of the domestic transportation problems by allowing access to rail by several of the southern district mines. However, freight charges associated with this form of transport, indeed, with all coal transportation, have contributed to the Australian coal industry's difficulties in competing with overseas suppliers such as South Africa.

With the downturn in the demand for steel on the world market, the Macarthur region has started to exploit its steaming coal reserves in order to keep up production. Markets which have included India, Bangladesh and Pakistan have emerged, but because these countries have relatively small ports the coal must be shipped in smaller lots. Consequently, the price of the coal is proportionately higher. The whole structure of Australia's coal transportation system, including the question of freight rates, requires investigation, and an overall strategy needs to be devised. It is hoped that this may be the subject of review during this Parliament.

What then is the future for the coal industry in both the Macarthur electorate and Australia generally? In the very long term the future is bright because the south coast underground reserves will far outlast open cut seams. In the short term the Australian Coal Association believes that south coast collieries must turn to steaming coal for their sales. However, the problem once again is that steaming coal pays a lower price for the same production costs. Hence, the Association has called for south coast mines to restructure to remain competitive. Once again, this returns the industry to the bleak prospect of mine closures and large scale retrenchments in the name of rationalisation. Not all in the industry would agree with the assertion that the future is bright. It is impossible to predict fluctuations in world demand for coal, in prices obtainable in a climate of fluctuations in currencies, and in the desires of coal companies to expand or contract in response to these and other factors.

In the last 10 years, all the export collieries in the southern coalfields have come under the control of multinational oil and mineral corporations. Although these companies have increased their level of investment in technological advances, the southern coalfields remain vulnerable to fluctuations in the international market and to the investment programs of companies with interests in minerals, oil and gas, in not only other parts of Australia, but also other parts of the world.

I was pleased to read of the success that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) was able to achieve with the British Petroleum company during his recent trip to Europe. The agreement reached in respect of Burragorang Valley mines has meant that jobs have been saved and mine closures averted for a period at least. Yet this serves as a typical example of how the problems of coal marketing and the progress of the Australian coal industry are dealt with on a piecemeal basis. No overall, co-ordinated strategy has been devised to ensure security of employment, equal access to markets at agreed to prices and even the basic allocation of new coal leases. Certainly, the establishment of the Coal Consultative Council by this Government in 1983 demonstrated the Australian Labor Party's commitment to becoming an active participant in the coal industry and to providing a framework for Government, companies and the trade unions to address the pressing problems of the industry. However, the crisis in the last year or so has clearly demonstrated the need for continued Federal intervention in price and tonnage negotiations and in the overall control of the industry. Labor Party policy calls for the establishment of a coal industry authority charged with responsibility for redressing these problems. Something must be done and done now, otherwise miners in the Macarthur electorate and in other mining areas of Australia will face a bleak future, a future which could see the continued economic and social decline of whole communities dependent on the mining sector.

I believe that these two matters on which I have touched are of universal concern across a broad spectrum of ages and classes. However, I now turn to an issue of equal, if not greater, significance to every Australian. I refer to the problem of youth unemployment, which remains one of the great social tragedies of our time. January figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicated that between 1973 and 1983 the unemployment rate among teenagers increased by 18 per cent, three times the increase in the adult rate. Although Australia's overall unemployment rate has dropped to 8.5 per cent, which gives testimony to the Government's economic policies, the unemployment rate for teenagers is still a massive 21 per cent. Sadly, within the Illawarra-Macarthur region this figure has been estimated at 44 per cent for the 15 to 19 years age group and 37.1 per cent for the under 25 category.

Notwithstanding these figures, as stated by the Sydney Morning Herald, believe it or not, the Hawke Government can rightly claim to be the first Government to tackle the issue of youth unemployment comprehensively. Initiatives such as the Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs have presented the Government with options to consider and policy decisions to make. But, as that Committee rightly points out, it is not reasonable to expect that problems which have been accumulating over many years can be easily eliminated. It has to be realised by politicians, bureaucrats, the community and, certainly, Australia's youth that Australia's economy is inextricably linked to the economies of other countries and that changes in technology, industry rationalisation policies and educational opportunities for the acquisition of various skills will all affect employment opportunities in some way.

Participation by youth in the community through a variety of schemes has been a notable achievement of this Government. Empty rhetoric from opponents of the Government's policies has been unable to detract from the fact that schemes such as the community youth support scheme, the participation and equity program, the labour adjustment retraining arrangement and other youth training programs have achieved great success. It is a sad fact of life that, because of the trend to increasing casualisation of the work force, full time work has been difficult to get. School students effectively are depriving school leavers of either permanent part time or full time work. This increased casualisation is not because of high wages for school leavers, but rather a reflection of the extremely low wages paid to 15-year-old casual workers. Studies such as those by Justice Macken in New South Wales have shown that nearly two-thirds of part time positions are held by school students. Macken's suggestion of the freeing of the penalty rates system and an increase in junior wages may help convert jobs currently held by casual workers into full time or permanent part time work for school leavers.

It is fitting that 1985 has been designated International Youth Year because, as has so often been stated, the future of Australia rests with today's youth. This year provides a unique opportunity for governments, the community and the youth of Australia to work together in an atmosphere of concensus and commitment in an endeavour to come to grips with the complex nature of the problems, desires and ambitions of today's youth. It is equally fitting that the three themes of the International Year of Youth-participation, development and peace-parallel the Australian Labor Party's own policy on youth. Issues of education, drug abuse and nuclear disarmament deserve to be discussed at length by and for today's youth so that all Australians will create for themselves a fair and just society of which they can be proud. I believe that, as a parent, I have every right to insist that my children grow up in a society which is going to reflect the norms and aspirations of this Government. I believe that it is this Government alone which can provide that atmosphere for my children to grow up in.

I have touched on but three of the many issues of concern to my electorate and of great personal concern to me. I believe that this Government has the necessary credentials, commitment and competence to achieve great things, things that will benefit not only my electorate but also certainly Australia. My electorate certainly looks to this Government for its continued work and assistance. I am sure that my electorate will continue to support me as its member whilst ever this Government is delivering, and I am sure that this Government will continue to deliver. I thank honourable members for paying me the courtesy of listening to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Farrer, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies, although he may have some experience in other places.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —To represent the electorate of Farrer, stretching as it does from Mount Kosciusko, through Albury and Deniliquin to the South Australian border, is, indeed, a privilege. I thank my family and friends and my electors in Farrer who extended such strong support for me on 1 December 1984. I also thank my National Party supporters, both in the electorate and elsewhere, including my Federal Leader, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and my Deputy Leader, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt).

SPEECH.PARA: Farrer is a diverse electorate named after the famous wheat breeder, William Farrer. The electorate was originally created in 1949 and has undergone several changes to its boundaries. Under the 1984 redistribution it has perhaps become the most elongated, non-metropolitan electorate in Australia. It commences a short distance inland from the New South Wales south coast at Mount Kosciusko and then utilises the Murray River as its southern boundary for hundreds of kilometres and ends at the South Australian border, not a great distance from the suburbs of Adelaide.

In the east there is some magnificent mount- ainous terrain with the tourist gateway points of Tumbarumba and Khancoban. As one moves west the mountains give way to the foothills and plains with countless thousands of hectares of rolling farmlands and rural service towns along with irrigation farms and, in the far west, grazing tracts. The national growth centre, Albury, is the largest city in the Farrer electorate and is its effective capital. Many State and Federal departments have large regional headquarters at Albury. I might add that these are staffed in the main by efficient and effective public servants who properly provide considerable liaison assistance along with the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation. Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd, Borg-Warner (Australia) Ltd and Macquarie Worsteds Ltd head the list of firms associated with the expanding industrial base. Along with this, equally important employment is generated through tourism in all its facets, including an expanded convention role for Albury.

Outside Albury there is a series of large and small country towns battling for survival as the rural service town role contracts. The one except- ion is a bevy of towns along the Murray River in what I term 'the border club belt'. They are booming, particularly since the Victorian Government reaffirmed its opposition to poker machines. There are record levels of investment in clubs and motels from Albury to Wentworth.

The electorate of Farrer has had only two other representatives since it was created in 1949. I pay sincere tribute to a former Minister of the Crown and Ambassador to Holland, Sir David Fairbairn, and also to my immediate predecessor, a former Minister of the Crown, the present honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife). I also pay tribute to my National Party colleague who effectively represented the western quarter of Farrer, the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks), and to the former member for Hume, Stephen Lusher, for his decade of service. I take this opportunity to congratulate the Speaker on his election and also Madam Deputy Speaker on her election. I am delighted that the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond) is the Deputy Speaker on this occasion, as we share a common town of interest. We were both brought up in the Boree Creek-Lockhart area.

In many ways Australia is at the crossroads, both on the international and domestic fronts. However, this situation is not reflected in the Governor-General's address. While the international front will be dealt with by many other speakers in the course of this debate, I say only that the vast majority of Australians deeply resent the U-turn in the Australian-United States of America relationship arising from a telephone call from Senator Richardson, ensconced in Japan, to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), then ensconced in Europe. Those of us who were randomly selected by this Parliament to be involved in the ugly conflict of Vietnam at times thought that, if nothing else, as one of the few Western nations fighting alongside the United States of America, we were contributing to the special nature of the relationship between Australia and America. It will take years and a change of government here to rectify the damage to our Australian-American relationship over the last month. It could be a very lonely future for Australia without a special relationship with the United States, as we need the United States, nuclear warts and all, more than it needs us.

I wish to raise four particular areas on the domestic front. Firstly, I mention the Murray Valley where salinity has reached a crisis situation and with it the health of many people, including the people of Adelaide. Secondly, I mention the farm sector of the economy, which is in a crucial situation, as are many of its commodities. Thirdly, I mention tourism, particularly inland tourism, which is at the crossroads. Fourthly, I mention transport in Australia which is also at a critical stage, with inefficiencies, be they in relation to air, rail or road, and with crippling fuel taxation. Before dealing in detail with these four areas let me be clear about my overall intent. My intent is not only to provide full time representation for all electors in Farrer but also to seek to better the well-being of our nation through less government and less taxation and the encouragement of individual enterprise. I quote a former great master of this House, Robert Gordon Menzies, who said:

The great race of man is that one in which each individual develops his fullest individuality, in which ambition is encouraged, in which there are rewards for the courageous and the enterprising, in which there is no foolish doctrine of equality between the active and the idle.

I might add that another former Prime Minister, John McEwen, put it more bluntly. He was 'for free enterprise, against socialism'. If Australia is to be in great shape in the bicentennial year of 1988, or more particularly, in the centennial year of 2001, when we celebrate 100 years of nationhood, 100 years of our Constitution and 100 years of the existence of this Parliament, Australians must have room to breathe from the high levels of taxation and room to be enterprising initiators. The individual entrepreneur must be unfettered so that he can go forward and generate economic activity and employment. I do not rule out a safety net under the truly needy. I am the first to recognise the huge and growing numbers of have-nots, be they farmers from Balranald or Berrigan or the young unemployed of the Lavingtons and Liverpools. However, I reiterate the general philosophy that less government and less taxation will do more to provide overall advancement than opposing alternatives and options, particularly heavy-handed big government requiring even bigger taxation.

I turn now to the first area I mentioned, namely, the Murray Valley and the related Murray-Darling system, which embraces part of Queensland and large areas of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. I have to tell the House that the salinity situation there is critical. Report after report and meeting after meeting catalogues the deteriorating situation. The most recent report, entitled 'Salt of the Earth', by the Victorian Parliamentary Salinity Committee is a further step forward.

Whilst a good deal of the salinity is naturally occurring, it is difficult to comprehend that annually around 1.1 million tonnes of salt pass in solution in the Murray River into South Australia from upstream. To this, South Australia adds another half million tonnes of salt, so that the salt load peaks in the Murray River at around 1.6 million tonnes annually. It is a chilling fact, detailed on page 46 of the report, that the water quality in the Adelaide pipeline off-takes has exceeded the World Health Organisation's long-term objective maximum for drinking water. This level is 480 milligrams per litre salinity, expressed in terms of soluble salts. Whilst I appreciate that there are other factors which dilute the intensity of salinity in the Adelaide water supply, including water from additional sources, some of those non-Murray River sources are just as bad for salinity as the Murray River itself. If I lived in Adelaide I would give up having salt as an additive. In any event, I gave up salt as an additive in October 1984-the same month as the Victorian report on salinity was published.

My plea is not just for the irrigators and the people of the towns and cities along the Murray; it is for the people of Adelaide and elsewhere. Progress is being made on combating salinity with some excellent work on interception by the River Murray Commission and other relevant New South Wales, Victorian and South Australian authorities. However, more needs to be done, and not necessarily with big ticket items costing millions of dollars. The planting of trees, the educating of irrigators and the speeding up of the responsible approach of the New South Wales rice industry and other industries to cease irrigating on leaky soils are all part of the solution. The Murray Valley League has an important role to play and will convene a forum on salinity. I will be working to see implemented the realistic recommendations of the various reports and, admittedly as a somewhat symbolic additional move, I will be seeking to see the headquarters of the River Murray Commission shifted out of Canberra, preferably to a grand location at Albury.

Moving on to the second area related to the crisis in the farm sector, I point out that the National Farmers Federation and farmers in general are not crying wolf at present. There is a notion around that somehow the farm sector will survive, that seasonal conditions are cyclical and will improve along with commodity prices and all will be well, particularly following the fall in the value of the dollar. It is not possible, due to time, to deal with each commodity situation such as milk, beef, wheat, sugar, dried fruits and rice. But on an overall basis it is a fact that a cost and price squeeze is destroying the viability of farming, notwithstanding valiant and successful attempts to lift farm productivity. The farming sector productivity cow has been milked dry. Without cost reductions or, alternatively, price increases, farmers in their hundreds, if not thousands, will go to the wall. Nobody wants subsidy for subsidy's sake as a solution, but farmers are entitled to a fair go, with better marketing, long-term low interest finance, a review of taxation on fuel and other key farm cost items and, in general, a sensitive approach by government at all levels to hold and bring about proper policies and priorities.

If the city commuter or the suburban parliamentarian feels that all of this is too much, may I remind the House that it was the breaking of the drought and the vast improvement in the rural sector of the economy that led this country out of the then recession, and all Australians can be thankful for that.

The dairy industry is currently in a hiatus and deserves special mention. I acknowledge the need exists to gain co-operation from the various State governments and this requirement has delayed the action of the Federal Government thus far; but I also suspect there are other reasons for the delay. I am advised that a senior officer of the Federal Department of Primary Industry has said that some 5,000 dairy farmers across the nation will have to leave the industry. It would be very wrong for the turmoil in the dairy industry to be allowed to continue to help pave the way for this and I reiterate my support for the Australian Dairy Industry Conference amended national marketing plan, as this is the correct approach and any outbreak of interstate milk war will, in the long term, be devastating for all dairy farmers.

I turn now to the question of tourism and the need to further boost tourism in Australia, with reference to the inland areas. To a large extent, there is a lack of realisation that there are many family-oriented, low-cost tourist activities available across inland Australia. Whilst these activities relate to locations which do not enjoy the same degree of exotic attraction as coastal areas and overseas, they nevertheless help complement and balance the tourist resources available in this country. The activities and locations to which I refer range from climbing Mount Kosciusko, which I did recently to visit the easternmost point of my electorate and familiarise myself with the Kosciusko National Park, to canoeing down the Murray River or hiring houseboats near the confluence of the Darling and Murray Rivers at Wentworth. Obviously there are many more activities which can be pursued across inland Australia and considerable progress has been made in further developing tourism.

However, one of the critical problems is high penalty rates for weekend work. These high penalty rates, applicable across large sections of the tourist industry, bring about additional costs for tourists or fewer services being available for tourists on public holidays and weekends. Even the Federal Minister for tourism at one stage indicated his concern about this issue, but the problem still remains and is seriously hampering the tremendous boost for the tourist industry throughout Australia. I am certain that if there were a trial period of two years allowing more flexible contract-related award rates in the tourist industry, with expanded provision for youth awards, many more jobs would be created in the tourist industry and related service industries. The bonus would be that these jobs would be in decentralised locations across Australia and I urge the Government to press on with expanding tourism in Australia.

I refer to the fourth and final area of transport being at the crossroads. Part of the problem relates to the level of fuel taxation currently being applied in Australia by the Federal Government in particular, but also by State governments with the one exception of Queensland, where no State fuel tax levy exists. For every dollar spent on fuel, the average level of taxation now exceeds 54c. The breakdown is: Commonwealth excise, approximately 19c; Federal royalties, approximately 2c; Commonwealth crude oil levy, now 27c; and, in the case of New South Wales, the State fuel tax levy, 7c. That is a total now of 55c in the dollar in taxation in respect of every dollar spent on fuel. This level of fuel taxation is particularly crippling to those people and those industries with no access to subsidised public transport. It is a massive burden on people in country Australia, including people living in the provincial cities, especially those families who have to run two vehicles because there is simply no commuter transport available to get to and from work.

This would not be so difficult to put up with if all or most of the fuel taxation was being returned to building a better transport system with better roads and bridges. However, governments of all political persuasions are guilty of ensuring that this is not the case and currently some 78 per cent of taxation collected from fuel is returned to Consolidated Revenue. It is desirable that the forthcoming summit on taxation should look carefully at the whole package of taxation associated with fuel in Australia, with a particular objective of reviewing that portion of the taxation which is not being returned to roads. It should also look at the anomaly relating to primary producers on the averaging system.

Perhaps it is a little unfashionable, but I also reiterate my strong support for the future role of the railway mode of transport, admittedly in a modernised form. It is exciting to learn that in the course of 10 years in the United States, the consolidated government-owned Conrail Corporation has moved back into the black and dramatically increased freight tonnages. Sadly, Amtrak, the equivalent American passenger rail corporation, has not made it into the black, but parts of its operation are profitable and some, but not all, United States rail operation lessons should be applied to the Australian scene. The most important transport corridor in Australia is Sydney-Canberra-Albury-Melbourne. It is the only corridor that enjoys the throughput created by having cities of more than three million people at either end.

It is my belief that we should be planning ahead for the centennial year of 2001. It was a bitter disappointment to see the exciting proposal prepared by Dr Paul Wild of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation for a TGV-type super-train system between Sydney and Melbourne rejected before it had really seen the light of day or been properly investigated. There should be a further wide ranging investigation of the super-train proposal between Sydney and Melbourne, but utilising the Sydney-Canberra-Albury-Melbourne route. With the improved economics available this, perhaps, might bring about viability for the scheme, especially if private enterprise is utilised throughout the implementation of a TGV-type super-train system between Sydney and Melbourne. As an example of lateral thinking, perhaps, I might add that the TGV-type 2 hour 40 minute service between Sydney and Melbourne would eliminate to a large extent the need for a second major airport at Sydney and the $1.5 billion cost associated with it. It would also confer benefits on the existing rail systems through greatly speeding up connections, especially at such junction stations as Canberra and Albury-Wodonga. In conjunction with the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) and others, I will be continuing to press for a realistic investigation of that proposal.

As one of 294 members since Federation who have switched from a State parliament to the Federal Parliament, I thank the House for extending the courtesy of hearing me in silence, and I realise that this will not be the case in the future. But I look forward to the challenge of representing the electors of Farrer and helping to contribute to the betterment of our great nation.
