TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Capricornia, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask the House to extent to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As is the tradition, Mr Deputy Speaker, I join other members in congratulating Mr Speaker and Madam Deputy Speaker on their re-election to their high and honourable offices in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The electorate of Capricornia, since its creation in 1901, has been represented by parliamentarians who have served this House and their constituencies with dedication and in some cases with distinction. I consider myself fortunate to have known three of the previous Labor members on a close personal basis. The Hon. Frank Forde, who, like myself, was also a State member for Rockhampton, held many and varied positions in this Parliament, including that of Prime Minister of Australia. During his 25 years in Federal politics, from 1922 to 1946, he never wavered from his commitment to people or to his country, and that commitment remained with him until his recent passing.

George Henry Gray entered Federal politics in 1961 when he recaptured Capricornia for the Australian Labor Party after it had been almost 16 years in non-Labor hands. His untimely death in 1967 was a great personal loss to me, for it was through his encouragement and support that I joined the ALP and embarked on a career in politics. It is, however, to George Gray's successor and my predecessor that I wish to pay a particular and special tribute.

The Hon. Dr Douglas Nixon Everingham, Federal member for Capricornia from 1967 to 1975 and from 1977 to 1984, and Minister for Health in the Whitlam Labor Government, should never be forgotten by this House. He deserves special recognition for his contribution to humanity, not just as a parliamentarian, as a Minister and as a doctor, but moreover as a human being whose care and concern for others was always placed above his own ambitions, his own popularity and sometimes his own political preservation. Doug Everingham's electoral support transcended party-political boundaries, and I am indeed conscious of the personal challenge before me as I endeavour to emulate his 16 years of service to his electorate, to the Australian community and to mankind generally. I take this opportunity to place on record the thanks and appreciation of the people of central Queensland for a job well done and to wish both Doug and his wife Beverly a most satisfying retirement.

It was my intention to use this, my maiden speech, to canvass a number of issues which are of personal concern to me, including the problems confronting Australian seamen on the Australian National Line, the alarming drug problem in our nation and other matters affecting the State of Queensland, caused mainly by the incompetence and misguided policies of the National Party State Government. However, as there is a 20 minute limit on speeches, I intend to raise these issues at greater length at another time during the session.

As a former State parliamentarian, it is appropriate for me to make an observation about our system of federalism. During my 15 1/2 years in the Queensland Legislative Assembly, I saw this system in operation at close quarters-sometimes, I might add, being left aghast and amazed at how the principle of federalism could be misinterpreted, manipulated and blatantly twisted to suit the political advantage of the Bjelke-Petersen Government. But, setting that aside, I readily acknowledge the importance of the States within the Federal structure and I am cognisant of the role played by State governments and, in turn, local authorities in ensuring that the decision-making process operates on a more decentralised, people-oriented basis. However, I also recognise that more and more in today's society, there are matters which, in the interests of Australians as a whole, are better dealt with at the national level, irrespective of the fact that traditionally the relevant area of administration might come within the purview of the States.

I direct my remarks specifically to the issue of consumer product safety as it relates particularly to the recall of unsafe goods. This issue is of fundamental importance to every Australian consumer-to every man, woman and child in the nation. Product safety is a matter of life, death and possible lasting injury. Yet, despite its broad and vital significance for the community, there has been limited action taken in the legislative chambers of this land to alleviate and redress the numerous problems that have arisen in the Australian market-place because of the retailing of defective and dangerous products.

I doubt that any member of this House would deny the right of consumers to be able to buy goods which are safe and which do not pose a threat to their lives or health. Every Australian has the right to expect that products put on the market are adequately safe under conditions of normal use and/or foreseeable misuse, and certainly people have the right to expect that they will not be unreasonably exposed to any hazard to their life or health. Product safety has been addressed in part by the Parliament and by those of the States, but there is little uniformity in administration and there is, in my view, a serious shortcoming in what the relevant laws seek to achieve. I take the Trade Practices Act as an example. The objective of this legislation is to prevent unsafe goods from being sold on the Australian market. This is done by a series of product safety standards, many of which have been developed through the excellent work of the Standards Association of Australia. However, despite this legislation, despite the work of government agencies and despite supervision by the majority of manufacturers, defective and dangerous products are still reaching the shop shelves and are being bought by unsuspecting Australian consumers.

Legislatures, Federal, State and territorial, have the power to ban an unsafe product, but being able to ban is not enough. A product banned from sale under the Trade Practices Act is not necessarily recalled; nor is the public necessarily warned of the danger. The same applies under State and Territory laws and, as far as I am aware, no banned product in this nation has ever been recalled. Even though the power exists to ban the sale of unsafe goods, nowhere in Australia is there the power to recall those goods. The failure of this Parliament and of the States to develop an effective recall procedure for defective products has existed for too long and must not be allowed to continue.

I welcome the attention and the excellent coverage that has been given to this issue by the Age newspaper and encourage that newspaper in its endeavours to develop a public awareness of this problem. I welcome also the recent undertaking by the Federal Attorney-General, the Hon. Lionel Bowen, in his capacity as Minister responsible for consumer affairs, to raise the concept of a national consumer product safety commission at the May meeting of the nation's Ministers for Consumer Affairs. The problem of recalling unsafe goods is, however, not a new one. In 1978 Senator Gietzelt spoke on this issue in another place and since then there has been much discussion and deliberation by Ministers at the various levels of government, but regrettably there has been little positive or effective legislative action. In the Press release of 16 September 1983 the Standing Committee of Ministers for Consumer Affairs 'expressed strong concern that although the Commonwealth, most States and territories, had legislation giving power to ban unsafe products, there was presently no legal power to compel the recall of banned products'. That was 18 months ago. Those Ministers clearly realised the shortcomings of the law but nothing has been done to rectify the situation.

In the United States there has been national mandatory recall legislation since 1972, and some of the States took action even as far back as 1906. In the United States, manufacturers know that if their product is found to be hazardous, a certain procedure must be followed to ensure that the product comes off the market and that the public is immediately warned of the danger. In Australia, there is no such requirement. In this country there is even great difficulty in getting agreement as to what is a safety related defect. One government authority may act against a product but there is no guarantee that others will follow suit.

A State by State comparison chart was published last week by the Age of more than 50 products which had been banned by a government somewhere in Australia. Not one of the products listed has been banned across the nation despite the danger to life or health and the risk of injury and many have been banned by only a minority of authorities. For example, the Magic Water Snake, containing water contaminated with human sewage, was banned only in Queensland. The Grazyfoam, an inflammable aerosol bath foam for children, was banned only in New South Wales. The Espree Magwheel Cleaner, which contains a hazardous concentration of hydrofluoric acid, was banned only in South Australia. Swimming pool skimmer boxes shaped like a child's potty, but which could disembowel children if sat upon, were banned only in New South Wales. The World's Cutest Doll, the head of which is easily detached, revealing a long metal spike, was banned only in Western Australia. The Gen Bag, a portable container used for the emergency transport of fuel, but found to be unsafe for that purpose, was banned only in Victoria. Sesame Street Jewellery, containing a high lead content, was banned only in Western Australia.

Tasmania is the only State to have banned a baby rattle which incorporates a series of steel prongs. The Trade Practices Commission is the only body to have banned an electric shock attache case which gives more than the thief a volt. Only the Northern Territory and Tasmania have acted against a brand of wire disc paint stripper which can break up, causing injury to the user. There are 30 other products which have been found to be dangerous but which have been banned by three or fewer of the State, Commonwealth and Territory authorities.

Regrettably, products declared unsafe in one State can quite legally remain on the market in another State. A recent example of this was 'the Magic Egg'. This product was promoted as a 'wonder growing pet', and consisted of small plastic toys which expanded up to 10 times their size when immersed in water. I need to say little more about the danger the toys posed to children when swallowed. It was banned first in the Australian Capital Territory and later by the Trade Practices Commission, then in Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia, and Western Australia; but it is still able to be sold in Queensland, Tasmania and the Northern Territory.

It is not unknown for manufacturers faced with a ban on their product in one State to dump it in another until the system catches up with it. I believe there is too much reliance on self-regulation by manufacturers, too much reliance on self-imposed but basically unenforceable codes of conduct and too much reliance on the hope that the manufacturers' sense of responsibility will overcome commercial considerations. I appreciate that most manufacturers are responsible and that they take every step to warn the public of any possible danger. I know also of manufacturers who are not so responsible. I know of those who cannot recall their products even if they want to. A tragic example of this was the case of the salami-salmonella outbreak in 1981. Because the manufacturer did not have any way of identifying the defective product, or knowing to whom it was sold, it was not possible to mount a recall and great suffering followed with more than 200 people across Australia being hospitalised.

The market-place must also contend with the rogue operators who are not bound by any code of conduct except self-interest and who are a threat to consumers and also to responsible manufacturers. Equally, of course, there are some very large corporations which have allowed commercial considerations, or what I call their cash register consciences, to overcome their social responsibilities and which pay no more than lip service to recalls.
I support this claim with the June 1980 report on tyre safety by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety. Paragraph 157 of that report said:

It is concluded that one Australian tyre manufacturer acted irresponsibly in not recalling tyres produced in the initial stages of its steel-belted radial production which the manufacturers knew were failing at an unacceptably high rate and were thus placing many people at risk.

There have also been instances where there have been unacceptable delays between the discovery of the defect and the warning to the public. For example, a distributor of Ducati motorcycles took 2 months grudgingly to agree to replace the alloy wheels on those machines, despite the public revelation that the wheels were collapsing. In 1981, even after considerable pressure from the Australian Automobile Association, it took the Ford company seven months to notify the public of a fault in its Cortina models made between 1971 and 1974. The fault was a carburettor fitting which sometimes allowed the fuel line to loosen and spray fuel over the engine, resulting in an unusually high number of under-bonnet fires. Ford rejected the request for a recall of the 40,000 vehicles involved but finally placed notices in newspapers referring to a special field action that the company was undertaking on these cars. This is just one instance where manufacturers have used any other word but the word 'recall'-an instance where the public had no indication of the fact that the car might have some safety related defect.

There are also the hidden recalls. In the case of the Volvo company in 1981, the cars were not recalled; instead the owners of a particular model were invited to bring their cars in for inspection. As well as the hidden recalls, there are also those which are tucked away in the classifieds section of the major dailies-the buried recalls, as I call them. One notorious example of this was in relation to a baby thermal feeding bowl-a bowl which, if a certain part was removed, could choke or scald the child. The advertisement placed by the manufacturer measured only four centimetres deep by one column wide-about the size of a postage stamp.

I do not believe in government regulation for its own sake. If self-regulation works, I prefer it that way. But self-regulation in this field of product safety has failed, and there are many responsible bodies and organisations that clearly concur with that opinion. The Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers said of voluntary recall codes:
They appeared often to have been honoured more in the breach than in the observance.
The National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council in its 1984 report said:
There is a demonstrated need for some form of government regulation of product recall in Australia.
The Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations said recently:
There is no way of monitoring if producers are adhering to their codes or not, and companies outside industry associations are not controlled even by voluntary codes.
It went on to say:
Voluntary recall codes are deficient and offer little or no protection to consumers.
AFCO went on to say:
A mandatory recall code must be introduced under which products must be recalled within a specified minimum time of being found dangerous.
In 1981 the Victorian Consumer Affairs Council advocated recall legislation, and as long ago as 1974 the National Committee of Inquiry on Compensation and Rehabilitation in Australia recommended:
There should be provision to order the manufacturer to recall, repair, replace, or provide a refund for a defective or dangerous product.
It also recommended that such a law should be a Federal, not a State, law. The Committee of Inquiry said:
Safety is a national concern and the manufacture, sale and distribution of products is not and cannot be confined within state boundaries.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety recommended, inter alia, that the Government introduce legislation to require the recall of defective or unsafe products. That was in June 1980.

The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, of which Australia is a member, has also recommended that member nations legislate or act, firstly, to ensure that consumers are warned without delay of products which present a substantial and severe hazard and, secondly, to enable unsafe products to be recalled. When considering this matter, it is necessary for honourable members to understand that Australia has developed as a national market and that only one statute should deal with the recall of goods. Moreover, where safety is involved the ability to take urgent action is essential and this cannot always be achieved with seven different laws. There is growing and widespread recognition of the need for mandatory product recall procedures to deal with the situation where there is a safety related defect. Why then, I ask, is it so difficult to make progress in Australia? I suggest the reason stems from a reluctance on the part of this Parliament, regardless of who has occupied the treasury bench, to act for fear of upsetting the States and Territories and of being accused of encroaching on their traditional legislative domain within our Federal structure. It is an understandable attitude, but it is no longer acceptable-certainly not to me.

The issue of product safety and the recall of hazardous goods is, as I have demonstrated, a problem of national dimension. It is a problem that calls for a national response, not just a patchwork approach by interested State legislatures. It calls for positive national leadership by this Parliament. There is an urgency for this Parliament to act to guarantee that product safety exists in the market place by ensuring not only that dangerous goods are banned but also that a mandatory warning and recall procedure or code exists-a procedure which can be implemented quickly and which can be enforced Australia-wide. It is my hope that this, the Thirty-fourth Australian Parliament, will mark a new era for consumerism in this country and that through its legislative efforts a swift end will be put to the prevailing practice of hazardous products continuing to be sold in the market place despite the exposure, despite the condemnation, and despite the banning by responsible authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Moncrieff, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask the House to extend to her the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. In common with several other speakers this afternoon, whilst this is my maiden speech in this place, and for the electorate of Moncrieff, I am now not new to the forms of parliament. However, I am delighted that you are in the chair for my maiden speech and I ask you to convey to the Speaker and to the Deputy Speaker my congratulations on their election to their positions and my hope that I will serve in this place for a long time, perhaps in their company.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had the opportunity to serve the people of Queensland in the Australian Senate for 10 years but I am particularly delighted that the people of Moncrieff have given me this opportunity to serve in the house of government in the national Parliament. I take this opportunity, as is traditional in maiden speeches, to convey my thanks to those people and to some others. My thanks go to Liberal Party supporters in Moncrieff, who showed incredible dedication to the cause of the Liberal Party winning the seat. I thank my Liberal Senate and House of Representatives colleagues who gave me guidance and personal support throughout the campaign, and in particular the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), a former member for the electorate of Fadden, and the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), both of whom, as Liberal members of the House of Representatives have represented, those areas which now make up the new Federal electorate of Moncrieff. I thank my husband for his personal and practical support as he underwent the experience for the first time of the hurly-burly of an Australian election campaign. I pay special tribute and convey special thanks to my parliamentary leader, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), for the leadership he gave to the Liberal Party in the election campaign and to all its candidates, myself included, particularly because of his personal support on two occasions in the electorate of Moncrieff. I believe that it was his unswerving faith in the principles and policies of the Liberal Party and his unflagging energy and enthusiasm for the task in hand that lead us to the success we had. He certainly made a major contribution to my success, for which I shall always be grateful.

Not only am I making my maiden speech as the member for Moncrieff but also I have the great privilege of being the first member for that new Federal electorate. I congratulate the Australian Electoral Commission for its decision to honour Gladys Moncrieff in this way. She was a great Australian and one of its most truly loved citizens. Born in Bundaberg in 1896, she, unlike the daughters of many parents in those days, was supported by her parents in her ambition to have a stage career. She was also supported by people of the community from which she departed-that is, Townsville-to make her name in Sydney. She was highly successful in vaudeville and with the encouragement of, amongst other people, another great Australian, Dame Nellie Melba, joined J. C. Williamson's where she had a very successful career in musical comedy. It was in 1921, at the age of 30, that she first played the role of Teresa in Maid of the Mountains and she was known forever afterwards to all Australians as 'Our Glad'. She was a smash hit in this role and in her lifetime gave more than 3,000 performances of it. While she was successful in many other roles, that is the one with which she has always been most closely identified.

She had successful visits to Britain, New Zealand and South Africa but, while she received critical acclaim in those countries, by her own choice she chose to stay in Australia for her entire career rather than seek international fame. She did many things in her lifetime but she will be well remembered for coming out of retirement to visit New Guinea to sing to Australian troops during World War II and for touring cities and country towns throughout Australia in support of the war effort. She came out of retirement once more to go to Korea when Australian troops were sent there and, in fact, she was the first Australian entertainer to visit Korea to lift the morale of the Australian troops involved in those hostilities. For her support of Australian troops in theatres of war she was awarded the OBE. She was famous for, amongst other things, her numerous retirements. She tried to retire on many occasions but the Australian public just did not want to let her go because they treasured her sweet voice and personality.

Finally, in 1963 at the age of 71 years, she retired to the Isle of Capri on the Gold Coast. Whilst she might have enjoyed a well earned retirement, she also enjoyed promoting the Gold Coast and tourism, its great industry. Canal boats that took tourists through the waterways of the Gold Coast used to detour through the canal on which her home was built and she would frequently appear to greet those on the boats. She is well loved and remembered on the Gold Coast for that and for her personal support of the tourism industry. She died in 1978 at the age of 84 years and she was mourned widely. Many felt that her death was a loss to the Australian family. I will leave my final word on her to a quotation from the book 100 Famous Australian Lives:

Someone once described Gladys Moncrieff's career as a long love affair between an actress and an entire nation. But perhaps that is incorrect in one detail. Nearly all love affairs have ups and downs-the rough with the smooth. But for Gladys Moncrieff, once she had captured the hearts of a whole country, there were never any fallings out of favour. The Australian general public loved 'our Glad' fiercely from the time she first came to their attention . . .

The electorate of Moncrieff is very large-over 3,000 square kilometres-varied and very fast growing. It has an annual increase in population of between 30 and 40 per cent per annum. It comprises parts of three local authorities-the Beaudesert and Albert shires and Gold Coast City. As I have mentioned, it was previously part of the old electorates of McPherson and Fadden. It is very rich in resources, both physical and human. Amongst its physical resources are fertile land and great natural beauty. That land supports the major rural industries of beef, dairying, sugar and small crops, and the area is a major centre in Australia for growing rhubarb and avocados. Its natural beauty is well known. It is famous for its beaches and waterways of the Gold Coast and the mountains and national parks of Tamborine and the Queensland-New South Wales border.

But to these great riches have come human resources and it is noteworthy that there is a very high concentration of small entrepreneurs throughout the electorate. The small entrepreneurs have built the Gold Coast to what it is today-the premier tourist resort in Australia. Tourism on the Gold Coast has been built up by small business people and therefore those things that affect small business very much affect it. In recent years major hotel corporations have also established themselves and are continuing to establish themselves on the Gold Coast but the region's source, its backbone and continuing prosperity will depend on the small person. Farmers also utilising the rich natural resources of the soil are small business people. They are important particularly in the Beaudesert area of the electorate. Unlike many country towns of Australia, Beaudesert is growing and prospering. I know from my time representing Queensland in the Senate that that is not a general story about country towns these days. Too many are stagnating or sliding back, wondering about their future, but the future of this area is assured. The third major centre of population is Beenleigh, which was previously a small country town. Sugar is still a major industry there; nevertheless Beenleigh has been caught up in the urban sprawl of Brisbane and is rapidly becoming a satellite of that city. I might say that the major industry in Beenleigh is people and it has a great future.

However, my electorate does have problems. Its principal problem is the Hawke Government. The last election saw a 2 per cent swing against Labor and also a substantial swing against the Australian Democrats. Before the Labor Party retreats in its thinking and chooses to put that fact into the pigeon-hole labelled 'informal' I would like to inform the House that I personally examined the recounted informal vote in Moncrieff. I can state as a fact that the electorate was confused by the change of voting system. A large number of those informal votes showed just the figure '1' against a candidates' name. I am sure that the people who voted that way believed that they had voted formally because voting in that manner constituted a formal vote for the Senate. However, that type of informal vote was split 50-50 between the Labor Party and the coalition parties.

There was no particular disadvantage to the Labor Party in the informal vote in Moncrieff. The swing against it and the swing to the coalition parties were genuine indications of disillusionment on behalf of the electorate and a growing apprehension at the future of this country under the Hawke Government. That disillusionment stemmed from the contrast between promises and performance of the Hawke Government. The growing apprehension stems from the effect of policies it had already enacted which reduce individual choice in this country and which people fear are leading to irrevocable changes in our way of life.

An outstanding feature of the population of Moncrieff is that it has a very high proportion of retirees and very young people. The extremes of age groups are very high in proportion to the total population. I will mention during my speech some matters that particularly impinge on those age groups but I want also to talk about some other matters that concern me as I know they concern the people whom I represent. It is fortunate for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that he did not keep his 1983 election promise to serve his full term. I have no doubt at all that, in the light of the MX missile affair and the response to it that I have had within my electorate, had the Prime Minister delayed the election until May this year this Government would have been out on its ear. So shortly after its re-election it has shown its Achilles heel, its inability to deal resolutely with things which are of extreme national significance.

There are ongoing issues and there will be issues in the future which will lead to a steady erosion of support for the Labor Party. I believe that at the next election this Government will be out and there will be a return of the Liberal-National Party coalition. As this Government continues in office and as more of its policies are implemented people will have a growing awareness-they had only the beginning of an awareness in the last election-of what a Labor Government means. As this Government steadily implements its truly socialist objectives while speaking softly and wearing velvet gloves, nevertheless the electorate knows what is happening because people are affected.

A classic case, probably more pointed in Queensland than in other States, nevertheless relevant in other States, has been the introduction of Medicare, the classic two-card trick. It costs more and you get less. It costs more because of the levy and the fact that those who still choose to insure themselves privately are paying far higher rates, together with losing tax deductibility for the rates that they pay. I am sure that it came as a rude shock to people in February last year when they made the necessary readjustments to their health insurance to discover that there was to be no gap insurance. I, along with many other members of parliament, received many inquiries and complaints about the inability of people to have something that they had before. Previously, those who chose to insure themselves privately could choose the percentage of their insurance. Having lost medical insurance rights they now find that they will get only 85 per cent of the scheduled rebate fee. Many of them asked why. Why indeed! Why would it matter to a government whether people had insurance in this basic area of need-health care? It should not matter at all to the finances of the Government if people choose to do that. But that is a decision that was made in line with socialist objectives.

This Government's objectives in relation to our health scheme are no secret. We do not want the British health scheme. We do not want to see happening in Australia what has happened in Britain-a perfectly good and outstanding health scheme reduced in so many areas. We have had a good health scheme for many years. If this Government truly consulted the people of Australia and stated what its ultimate objectives in the health area were I am sure that it would be roundly rejected on that base if on none other.

Another area which affects the very high number of retirees that I have in my electorate-it does not affect just them; it affects all people-has been the Government's move in the areas of superannuation taxation and the assets test. The most profound thing that one can do to affect people's behaviour throughout their lives is to structure or influence their expectations about their retirement. People, throughout their lives, work and plan for that time of their lives when they will no longer work, either because they do not want to or because they cannot. They make economic and behavioural decisions throughout their lives in line with those expectations.

I ask as I did in relation to Medicare: Why would the Government have initiated this move on taxation of lump sum superannuation? It is known that there is virtually no immediate benefit to the Government in terms of taxation revenue. It is estimated that it will take at least 10 years before the full effect of revenue from this flows into the Government's coffers and becomes significant. Why then would a government risk unpopularity by this sort of move? It is because it has long term objectives. Those objectives are in line with the action it has taken on the assets test. It intends to structure and limit Australians' options in retirement. It suits socialist governments for citizens not to be independent of them and not to have rights of choice. It suits governments to have them dependent on bureaucracy and government directive because then government can limit options. The more limit there is and the more effective it is the cheaper it gets for government. Truly, those who have been affected by these two measures and those who will be affected have very good reason for apprehension at the introduction of a capital gains tax and estate duties. These are two more taxes of the same kind. They limit people's choices, they limit their rights, they limit their horizons and, inevitably, they limit their behaviour throughout their lives. If people believe that it is better to spend rather than invest because they will only be penalised-that is a comment that has been made to me by plenty of people as I have travelled around my electorate and around Australia-we will have a very different sort of Australia in 20 years time. I believe that nobody would have voted for this Government in 1983 or 1984 if he or she had truly understood this.

The plight of the young is a matter that is canvassed frequently and I am sure that it will be canvassed in the future. Time will not permit me to say very much on this matter. The statement in the Governor-General's Speech relating to education participation is one of the greatest frauds of all times. I am pleased that none of the Government speakers has chosen to refer to it. Whilst the Government announced that it was going to increase the number of people participating in tertiary education it did not give those tertiary institutions the resources they needed to provide that number of places. It is nonsense for the Government to say to universities, colleges and technical colleges that they must take so many more students but with only a marginal increase in funding, and then to claim that one has done one's best to increase participation. It does not wash and the figures will show that. The alternative would be a lowering of standards. It will be interesting to see whether Professor Peter Karmel has any comment to make on that aspect of standards in education in Australia in the report he is due to give to the Government, according to the Governor-General's Speech.

For many young people the Community Employment Program has been a tragic let down. This Government has created a bucket and shovel brigade. It has set up CEP projects in my electorate using antiquated methods that I had not seen in my lifetime. Far from giving to young people some skills that they could offer to employers, because of the artificial requirements for labour intensity all we are giving them is temporary and tantalising employment. We are not giving them skills that employers truly need.

Finally, I refer to the frauds that are being perpetrated in the primary industry area. The sugar and dairy industries are two very large industries in my electorate. They are two highly significant rural industries in Australia. I very much doubt that the sugar farmers will ever be sweet-talked by this Prime Minister again. He has done it twice and they have seen nothing for their conversations and conferences with him. It appears that the dairying industry problems now move towards resolution, no thanks at all to the Hawke Government. In view of the great public expectations that the Australian people had of the Hawke Government when they first elected it, it is sad that those expectations have been dashed. There were some fine words in the Governor-General's Speech. I am sure the Prime Minister will continue to offer us fine words, both in this forum and in other places throughout Australia. However, this Government will be judged on its deeds, not on its words, and that will lead to its inevitable failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Dobell, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I congratulate you on your election to the office of Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives. I hope that you will convey my congratulations to the Speaker and Chairman of Committees. I am sure that you will all discharge your responsibilities with great distinction.

SPEECH.PARA: On 1 December 1984, a clear majority of Australians cast their votes for the Australian Labor Party. A clear and sizable majority of Australians voted to endorse the Hawke Government's mandate for continued economic recovery and reconstruction. As the Australian Labor Party's candidate, I had the honour, on 1 December 1984, of being elected the first member for Dobell. As all honourable members would be aware, this new electorate has been named after Australia's greatest portrait painter, Sir William Dobell. In the words of his biographer, James Gleeson, this is what portraiture was to Dobell. Portraiture was a serious study in which he attempted with all the honesty, sensitivity and technical skill at his command to wrestle into paint the personality that lay within.

William Dobell lived at Wangi for 30 years. While working at Eraring power station I had the pleasure of meeting many of Bill Dobell's neighbours and friends. They all recalled his humility and friendship. Following the December election, I attended my first meeting of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party in the Government party room in this building. After observing that two of Dobell's greatest portraits, the Billy Boy and the Cement Worker, dominate one wall of the party room, I can only conclude that the good judgment of the Labor Caucus extends to art as well as to government administration.

Prior to the 1984 redistribution, the constituents of the electorate of Dobell were represented by three distinguished members of this House. The honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), who now serves his country as Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, represented most of the electorate of Dobell during his 15 years in the House of Representatives. His reputation on the central coast as a hard working local member is well deserved. The honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) will, I believe, be remembered as Australia's most energetic and reformist Minister for Transport since the Second World War. Both the honourable member for Robertson and the honourable member for Shortland have represented me in this House as my Federal member. However, I owe a different debt to my friend the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). The honourable member gave me, and many thousands of other students, a thorough grounding in economics and Australian economic history. If the many speeches in this chamber of the honourable member for Charlton continue to be unsuccessful in educating members of the Opposition, I am prepared to provide the Liberal Party of Australia with a copy R. J. Brown's, Student Economics. I am sure that, with study, their standard of debate will improve. I am happy to acknowledge the assistance and advice these three colleagues have given me in recent days.

I come to this House at the comparatively young age of 27. I express to my family and friends on the central coast and in Cronulla my thanks for the help and assistance they have given to me over many years. I also thank the many hundreds of Labor Party members and supporters who worked so tirelessly during the election campaign. Without their help I would not be standing here today. I know that the second Hawke Government will continue to work to fulfil their hopes and dreams for a better Australia.

In 1972, 13 years ago, Australia's Prime Minister was Sir William McMahon. At that time the Liberal-Country Party coalition had been in power for 23 consecutive years. When our sportsmen and women were presented medals at the 1972 Munich Olympics, God Save the Queen was played as the Australian flag was raised. At that time, Australian troops were fighting in Vietnam. Young men were being conscripted for military service before they were eligible to vote. In 1972, Australia's foreign policy was subservient to that of the United States of America. The age pension paid to senior citizens was a miserly 20.3 per cent of average weekly earnings.

In October 1972 I joined the Cronulla Branch of the Australian Labor Party, mainly because its Federal Leader was Gough Whitlam. In the policy speech Gough Whitlam delivered at the Blacktown Civic Centre in November 1972, he stated that one of his aims was 'to liberate the talents and uplift the horizons of the Australian people'. One of the greatest achievements of the Whitlam Government was to place urban and regional development on the nation's agenda. On 16 August 1970, Gough Whitlam outlined the Australian Labor Party's policy in this area in these words:

Inequality in Australia is more public than private. A family's standard of living is determined much more by where they live than by what they earn. The inequalities between regions are now far greater than any between States, and indeed greater than they ever were between States. In developing regions the inequalities and the burdens are growing. The areas with the greatest needs are precisely those with the least resources. The Commonwealth Grants Commission was set up to advise the Commonwealth on the fairest way to help the smaller States provide services equal to those of the larger States. The Commission should now be asked to recommend the amount of Commonwealth assistance required to remove the inequalities in servicing our developing suburbs and regions.

If today Federal funding to local government were reviewed on that basis the local councils within the electorate of Dobell would rank as some of the most deprived in this country. This has been brought about by two factors: firstly, the area is growing rapidly. Since 1976, Wyong shire, which covers most of my electorate, has had an annual population increase of 8 per cent. Development in new areas has not been accompanied by the provision of essential community facilities, such as adequate roads, community halls, child care centres and sewerage reticulation. Secondly, our region includes a large number of underprivileged people. Unemployment is over 20 per cent, which is nearly twice the State average.

In the northern Sydney region of the New South Wales Department of Education, which extends from Sydney Harbour Bridge to the northern boundary of my electorate, 11 schools are considered to be disadvantaged under the assisted schools program. Every one of those schools is on the central coast and eight are within the electorate of Dobell. The social consequences of this region's deprivation is illustrated by the following two examples: Firstly, Wyong shire has the greatest number of individual juvenile cases in the north-east Sydney region. In 1980, 18 per cent of the total number of juvenile cases involved children from Wyong shire-I repeat 18 per cent-yet the shire's population is only 8 per cent of the region's population. Secondly, the percentage of people separated, divorced or widowed in Wyong shire at the time of the 1981 census was 12.6 per cent-1 1/2 times the New South Wales average.

Local councils within the electorate of Dobell cannot continue to increase revenue by raising rates without severely penalising many people on low incomes. I represent an area where, for the reason I have explained previously, local government has been unable to provide the services and facilities for which it is responsible. Local government in my electorate is in desperate need of increased funding. In my opinion, the national government has a responsibility to increase funding to local government in developing areas. On 28 May 1979, the Commonwealth Grants Commission presented the then Minister for Administrative Services, the Hon. John McLeay, with a special report on financial assistance for Local government. This report presented the Fraser Government with five options, including a proposal to allocate funding to local government on the basis of need. The Grants Commission recommended that the Government determine, as a matter of policy, which of the options it wished the Commission to adopt. As in so many areas of government administration, the Liberals refused to make a decision.

I admit that sometimes Australia was better off when the Fraser Government could not make a decision. Take, for example, its decision on the national sewerage program. This program was established by the Whitlam Government. In the three Whitlam Budgets this program received $28m, $117m and $112m. After the election of the Liberal-Country Party Government in 1975, funding for the national sewerage program was slashed to $48m in 1976 and in 1977 it was terminated. If this program had continued, many thousands of my constituents would now be living in sewered homes.

I note with satisfaction that this Government has established a national inquiry into local government finance to examine the matters which I have raised. I commend the Government and the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) for ensuring that the views of local government, community organisations and individuals are being heard by this inquiry. I can assure the House that I will be very interested in the inquiry's progress in future months. It is my hope and that of many of my constituents that the end result will be a fairer distribution of Federal funds to local government.

I turn to the New South Wales doctors' dispute and the impact it is having on the central coast of New South Wales. In the week before the election last December an anonymous group of doctors placed advertisements in local newspapers seeking to discredit me and my colleague the honourable member for Robertson by claiming that we were nationalising medicine. I quote from an interview with one of the anonymous doctors which was published in the Gosford Star, which I am sure all honourable members read-I am sure the honourable member for Robertson does-on Friday, 30 November 1984:
Doctors admitted their resignations this week-
this is the week before the Federal election-

were a final attempt to discredit the Government and emphasise their stand in the eyes of the public before the election. As one prominent specialist stated 'I am ruined on Saturday if the Government is returned'. Explaining the Government's attempts to rationalise the health system by stealth through Medicare, another specialist commented, 'they're really just communists out and out'. 'Their actions are based on the writings of Lenin'.

I think even the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) would not make such a ludicrous claim. These doctors, who obviously hold extreme right wing views, were simply trying to create fear amongst the people of the central coast. They were acting as the political operatives of the Liberal Party. As I explained earlier to the House, my electorate has one of the highest proportions of pensioner constituents. I now wish to read to the House a letter which one doctor is currently circulating to people in my electorate. It is entitled 'Notice to all Patients' and states:
The Bureaucratic machine is on the move.
Investigators from the Minister of Health's department are on the prowl in this Gosford district at present.
I have already been contacted by a patient who has been upset by their interrogation and felt she could not sleep until I assured her there was nothing to worry about.
Another patient is very angry at the prying attitude of the interrogators, and intends to protest to the Prime Minister.
I, personally, have nothing to hide, but I strongly resent the government's henchmen upsetting my patients with their visits and questions.
If you agree with me, why not make a fuss about it?
I can do nothing more than let you know what is going on, and hope that you will carry the baton from here on. Unless you do, believe me, things will get much worse for you, the patient.
I have worked in a socialistic, nationalised medical scheme, and I know what I'm talking about.

When someone seeks to gain political milage in this way by scaring pensioners and other patients, I believe he is beneath contempt. I wish to make it clear that the vast majority of doctors are not participating in this campaign, which is being organised by the radical specialists who seek to discredit and destroy Medicare. This campaign and the endless series of settlement negotiations have now reached their seventh month. Each time settlement has appeared close the radical surgeons, led by Dr Shepherd and Dr Aroney, have sabotaged the discussions. The truth is these people will not allow the dispute to be settled until Medicare is destroyed. The truth is these people are prepared to allow innocent patients to endure suffering and pain until Medicare is destroyed.

I am amazed that the Liberal Party, through the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and its former spokesman on health, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), is now supporting the radical surgeons. This places the Federal Liberal Party at odds with its New South Wales leader, who recently called for all parties to resume negotiations. This dispute will be resolved only when all parties are willing to compromise. On 20 January the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) offered concessions to the doctors. I understand that the Australian Medical Association will meet the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) later today for further discussions. The only two groups not prepared to seek a settlement are the radical surgeons and the Federal Liberal Party.

Before I conclude my remarks today, I draw the House's attention to an agreement signed last Sunday by the Victorian Premier, John Cain, the South Australian Premier, John Bannon, and the New South Wales Premier, Neville Wran. This historic memorandum will result in the construction of a $155m link between the Victorian and New South Wales electricity grid and the South Australian electricity power supply. Before becoming a member of this House I worked for many years as an electrical engineer with the Electricity Commission of New South Wales, and I would like to explain why this is a project of major significance. For many years New South Wales and Victoria have interchanged significant amounts of power through the Snowy Mountains scheme. When the three-State power grid project is completed Victoria, South Australia and New South Wales will be able to interchange power. This will provide industrial and domestic consumers in those three States, especially Victoria, with a more secure and stable electricity supply. At various times each State electricity authority will be able to reduce its costs of production by importing cheaper power. Gas turbine plants, which produce very expensive power and consume our relatively scarce hydrocarbon resources, will be used less frequently. I understand that the project will save consumers $14m every year. The historic agreement signed last Sunday by Premiers Cain, Wran and Bannon demonstrates what can be done when Labor leaders work together to build a better Australia.

Mr Speaker, I wholeheartedly support the second Hawke Government's program, as outlined in the Governor-General's Speech. The Government's program seeks to encourage all citizens to work together to build a better Australia. I thank the House for extending to me the courtesy of being heard in silence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for the Northern Territory, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, please accept my congratulations on your election to your high office. I certainly agree with the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) that a lot more money was needed for sewerage while the Whitlam Government was around. This Government, in outlining its programs for the next three years, speaks today of creating a stronger, fairer and more equitable Australian society. This commitment is of particular interest to the people I seek to represent both in the electorate of the Northern Territory and in my broader shadow ministerial responsibilities for local government and northern development. That is because the Territory electorate, the local government arena and all of northern Australia must rely upon the vision of the Government, to a considerable extent, for their sustenance and progress. Indeed, with the current media fad for naming members of this Parliament after their favourite occupations, I might be known as the member for the least influential. Certainly I would prefer that tag to the one of member for those under the influence, although that is how my areas of electoral and portfolio responsibilities might be seen.

SPEECH.PARA: More than most other Australians, those in the Northern Territory, local government and all of northern Australia are under the influence of decisions taken at the Federal level. The words 'creating a stronger, fairer and more equitable Australian society' are nice words and sound great. But does the reality match the rhetoric? I must say at the outset that I am not greatly encouraged by these words, despite, or perhaps because of, the familiar ring that they contain. I am not encouraged because-let us face it-they were practically the only words in the Governor-General's Speech on which we can hang our hats. There were precious few mentions of local government or of the north, although once again we are to be the guinea pigs. Cash up front for exploration licences is to get its Australian premiere in the waters to our north.

Honourable members will expect me to speak at length on the Northern Territory and I will not disappoint them, but, first, I shall deal briefly with the problems of local government. We are all familiar with local government. We tend to take it for granted. But the third tier of government deals with grass-roots problems, and with increasing pressures on its services and severe limitations on its revenue raising potential, local government is clearly headed for greater difficulties. As someone said at a recent local government conference, the Commonwealth Government has the money, the State governments have the power and local government has the problems. These problems cannot be solved by the Commonwealth alone. The States must be involved. My few short years in local government taught me that there are no easy solutions and it will take me some time to come to grips with those problems. But we will all certainly have to ensure that we do come to grips with them, or we will risk the wrath of the electorate at the grass-roots level.

I will be keeping a close eye on the work of the new Department of Community Services which has been given a brief to ensure that services are equitably distributed and better co-ordinated with those of the States, local government and community groups. Let us hope that this will not turn out to be just another departmental exercise in viewing grass-roots problems from on high, or a power grab by empire-building bureaucrats.

Turning now to my northern responsibilities, I recall the words of Prime Minister Alfred Deakin, who in 1904 asked Federal Parliament whether it was 'prepared to confess our incapacity to cope with the development of one half of Australia' north of a line from the Gascoyne River to Gladstone. I do not know whether the Parliament ever collectively made such a confession, but I do know that there are some three million square kilometres of northern Australia in which a little under 800,000 Australians live. That is about 48 per cent of our continent, containing about 5 per cent of our population, which seems to me to answer Mr Deakin's question. But there is hope. The Government now speaks of a more equitable Australia. That principle must apply on a geographic as well as a socio-economic basis.

We hear through the media that even the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) now sees the need for a railway to link north and south, if only to carry Federal funds to the Northern Territory. Last year in Adelaide the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), under some election pressure, I might add, said that the railway would eventually be built-no doubt recalling the promises given to South Australia and the Northern Territory by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) in the previous year, shortly before the 1983 election. It is true that they broke their promises, claiming that an unexpected deficit made the necessary expenditure impossible. Of course, the completion date could have been deferred beyond the projected 1988, to make allowance for the deficit, but that may have been too simple. Instead, the Government got Mr Hill of the State Rail Authority to invent a unique and incomprehensible methodology which, he said, made the railway not viable. The Minister for Transport is so proud of Mr Hill's methodology that he refused to release it to us under the Freedom of Information Act. The Government ignores the fact that the unquestionably independent Canadian Pacific Railway disagrees with it, that the Institute of Defence Studies recommends the project as a top defence priority and that the Department of the Arts, Heritage and Environment has recommended that, on social grounds, the railway should be built. Let us ignore altogether the Australian Labor Party's social audit approach to transport infrastructure. Of course, Australian governments have been promising the railway since 1910 so perhaps northern Australians might be forgiven for questioning the sincerity of this Government's commitment to a more equitable Australia.

Previous Labor governments did have a vision which, although we may not have agreed with it, did at least encompass all of Australia-although they also had Rex Patterson-while this Government seems to have little real interest in or sympathy with northern aspirations. Perhaps that is not so surprising as it has no Minister from further north than Ipswich. Certainly, the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) and the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) seem to be among the castrati of the fourth grade. It is just another example of the lack of influence of which I have spoken.

Let us contrast the Governor-General's Speech, which really only mentioned the north to tax it, with the 1982 ALP policy document 'North Queensland-Future Directions'. Of course, those were vote-grabbing days. I will cite some initiatives from that document:
Domestic passengers to be able to use the Townsville international terminal.
Air fare reductions through 'no frills' services.
Upgrading and increased local control of regional broadcasting.
An Inter-State Commission to ensure more equitable--
there is that phrase again-
transport costs.
Increased defence commitment to north Queensland, including five patrol boats to be built at Cairns.
Cut out sales tax on freight.
Sugar industry assistance.

There are a whole lot more. These initiatives are a reflection of north Queensland's problems. But today, it seems, the Government hopes that they will just go away. Of course, they will not. As for creating employment, so far 300 people have been laid off because of the failure to keep the promise on building patrol boats in Cairns.

Let us look at the sugar industry. Six hundred growers are likely to have to leave the industry and whole districts along the Queensland coast are dependent on it for their economic survival. In 1982, in 1983 and in 1984 this Government promised to give assistance to the industry, but to date absolutely nothing has been forthcoming. I can tell honourable members, from my recent visit to the area, that the growers in north Queensland are desperate. Why do not Government members go north and tell the people up there about a stronger, fairer and more equitable Australia?

We should pity the poor tobacco growers. I know it is not fashionable to talk about tobacco today, unless to sneer. But we are talking about equity and we are all agreed that we hold with that. We should spare a thought for the tobacco growers who are facing increasing pressure to become more competitive in what has always been a back-breaking family enterprise. Growers understand the need to be competitive but, first, they would like a more equitable share of the price of a packet of cigarettes. A packet of smokes costs up to $2, of which the grower receives a lousy 4c. From tobacco sales Australian tobacco growers receive about $70m while governments receive in excess of $1 billion in tax on tobacco products. Is that equity? So far it seems that the Government's commitment to equity does not stand up to closer scrutiny and nor do the Government's policies seem to assist a stronger Australia.

The north relies heavily on citizen forces for the defence of our coastline. The men and women who volunteer are often professional and technical experts who draw good salaries in their own right. Men and women of this calibre are required for the north-west mobile force-one of the most effective units we have-which operates from Arnhem Land to the Pilbara. But at the last Budget the Government decided to make our reservists pay tax on half of their Army pay. The result has been disastrous because the Government's decision has pushed them into the highest tax bracket. The result has been a loss of about 30 per cent of the force's manpower, and an even greater loss of morale.

What of policies leading to the current uranium debacle which has made us an international laughing stock? Is it fair and equitable to say to one State that it may go ahead with developing its uranium deposits while other States, and the Northern Territory, may not? Is mining uranium moral in some States and immoral in others? What sort of hypocritical, canting humbug is that? Do such policies make Australians stronger? Some figures may help this Parliament judge the answer to that. Conservative estimates are that the discounted value of national income generated if all current and proposed uranium mines in the Territory were allowed to proceed would be some $9,000m by the year 2000, of which $1,600m would stay in the Territory. The loss of income if only existing uranium mines are allowed to fill the existing contracts will be $6,300m by the year 2000, with the Territory missing out on $1,300m. While the north's potential continues to be strangled by this sort of Left-Right-Centre hybrid ideology, we will need a railway to freight Federal funds northwards. If the mines were allowed to proceed, we would need the railway to send those thousands of millions of dollars to Federal coffers. In addition, thousands of jobs would be generated, but honourable members opposite would prefer those jobs to be created in South Africa, Canada or Botswana-anywhere but Australia.

In that context, I deal with the apparent avowed intention of the Minister for Finance to sacrifice the Territory on the altar of cost savings. At self-government, a financial deal was struck with the Federal Government which sought only to bring services in the Territory up to the standards of New South Wales and Victoria. The financial formula was worked out to encourage and support population growth in the north. The agreement, under the memorandum of understanding, has gone a long way towards achieving those objectives. Honourable members should remember that when we negotiated that agreement against the might and resources of the Commonwealth, the Territory, before self-government, possessed just one Public Service level 1 financial adviser. There should be no need for me to assure this House that the Territory is not over-funded. The Commonwealth Grants Commission carries out an independent assessment and has found instead the need to top up funds. These financial arrangements make for a stronger, fairer and more equitable Australia, but it seems that they are now under attack. I ask honourable members what Federation is about if it is not to assist the disadvantaged areas of Australia; the Territory is, after all, one sixth of Australia. A mile of road in the Territory is no shorter or less costly to build.

I could hardly address this House without some reference to the land rights issue, although it seems to have been swept under the carpet in the Government's program. Land rights issues are different in each State and within States, but one thing is common to all States: There is enormous division about land rights in the community. We are now seeing divisions within the Government and within the Labor Party. The way in which land rights have been enacted and administered in the Territory has caused fear elsewhere. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) would do well, as he licks his wounds after his first term and ponders whether he will seek a closer acquaintance with the truth, to remember that the people on the ground have the most experience-the Territory has had eight years experience-of the effects of land rights.

Do honourable members opposite expect us to trust them after the king-hit decision about Ayers Rock? I have opposed land claims in the past, not because I am opposed to Aboriginals owning land, but because each successful claim amounts to a total alienation of any interest in the land the general community has. Aboriginal land should be held as far as possible on the same terms as land held by other Australians. I put some questions to honourable members. Should conversion of Territory land to Aboriginal freehold be completely open-ended? Should there be no government requirements on people to use pastoral land productively? Should land claims be allowed to be lodged repeatedly? Should there be no time limit for the lodgment and hearing of land claims? Should Crown land, including national parks already dedicated to a public purpose, be able to be claimed? If such claims are successful, should normal public access be denied? Finally, should the great majority of Aboriginals living on pastoral properties be prevented from gaining secure title to the land on which they live? Any honourable member who answers 'No' to only one of those questions believes that changes are necessary to the Land Rights Act in the Northern Territory.

Despite land rights legislation in the Territory, locking up almost half of the Territory to exploration, and despite the Government's uranium policies, Territorians, mainly through mining earnings, record a per capita export figure of some $4,000 per annum, as against an Australian average of a little over $1,000. Despite the odds, we are doing our best towards building a stronger Australia.

The Territory electorate has gained two new islands in the past year, Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. I will visit those islands at the first opportunity. There is one plane a week and my visit will entail a 4,000 kilometre journey into the Indian Ocean on top of my electoral duties across 1.4 million square kilometres of Australia. I know that the people of Christmas Island have their own land problems, since there is not one square centimetre of land available for islanders on a freehold or leasehold basis. This means no market gardening, no horticulture of any kind, and precious little in the way of commercial retail space, as the Australian Government and mining companies hold it all. I know too that in many cases housing is in short supply and not up to the standards that would be considered acceptable in other parts of Australia.

The Northern Territory, indeed all north Australia, is a resource rich and energetic region, contributing to national goals; in many cases it does so in spite of government policies. With our small population and lack of a protected manufacturing sector, we are geared up with the right policies to take maximum advantage of the technological, nuclear society.

I have said that I am the member for the least influential, for those who most rely on equity and fair dealing. Inhabitants of the three million square kilometres of north Australia have just seven members to fight on their behalf. I will finish by quoting the words of Senator John Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, in September 1982. If honourable members read 'north Australia' for 'north Queensland', the sentiments apply equally well. Senator Button said:

North Queensland is an area with great natural resources and its contribution to Australia's financial health and stability has always been high. But is has rarely received a fair return for its contribution to the national wealth and in recognition of its strategic position. National governments have never fully grasped their obligations to north Queensland. The ALP is determined that this situation must end.

The Government's program for the next three years goes nowhere near living up to those words. North Australians, indeed all Australians, look to this Government for action, not words. They hope for a government which will set the lead, and build a stronger, fairer and more equitable Australia by relying on individual competitiveness and the great wealth of natural resources that our nation contains.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Chifley, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I offer you my congratulations on your re-election to your high office. I wish also to be associated with congratulations to the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) on her election as Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees. I also thank you, Mr Speaker, and the Chairman of Committees, for the kindness and courtesy shown to me as a new member on the Government side. Indeed, that courtesy was shown to all new members on both Government and Opposition sides. I trust that I should not be disorderly if I say how pleased I was, as were a large number of Government members, to see a lady Serjeant-at-Arms at the opening of this Parliament. I am sure that many young women in my electorate will be inspired to aspire to positions which might otherwise be seen as male preserves.

SPEECH.PARA: I stand before my peers as the third member for Chifley. I thank my predecessors, John Armitage and the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Gorman), for the way in which they administered the electorate. I record my appreciation for the tremendous public support I received on election day and subsequently. It was a ringing endorsement of the Hawke Government's policies as they affect western Sydney in general and Chifley in particular. I pay a special tribute to my wife, Robyn, and my children, Michelle, Stephanie, Benjamin and Courtney, who have endured much and have never wavered in their support and encouragement. It is as much a win for my family as it is for me.

Victory in Chifley on 1 December largely reflected the tremendous dedication and commitment of the members of the Australian Labor Party who worked tirelessly throughout what was one of the longest campaigns on record. Organisationally, it was difficult for the Party to reform the Federal Electorate Council, hold a quick-fire preselection and then organise and raise funds for the campaign. However, the Party responded magnificently. I thank my friend and campaign director, Richard Amery, the State member for Riverstone and his Deputy, John Aqualina, the State member for Blacktown, the President of the FEC, Keith Squire, his executive and council, the seven branch campaign directors and all the branch members.

When one mentions individuals one can run the risk of offending those one omits. If I were properly to acknowledge those I would like to, or who merit it, I would run out of time. However, I mention two people. The first is Tony Johnston, the former State member for Riverstone-I was privileged to be his first campaign director some 13 years ago-and president of the State Electorate Council. I was pleased to be close to him and am indebted for the experience I gained. The other person is Alderman Sylvia Whilesmith, who has always been a very loyal and dedicated supporter and now is establishing her very own high credentials as the first ALP women alderman on Blacktown City Council and Chairperson of our Community Services Committee.

The seat of Chifley is situated in the western suburbs of Sydney, generally west of Parramatta and east of Penrith. It is the heartland of Labor's western stronghold. The heart of my electorate is Mount Druitt, where I am proud to say I live and where I have insisted on opening my electorate office. The people of Bidwill, Blackett, Dharruk, Emerton, Hebersham, Lethbridge Park, Shalvey, Shane Park, Tregear, Whalan and Willmot have a special place in my heart. They are not only part of Chifley electorate but form the fifth ward of Blacktown City Council. These good people are the ones who thrust me into public life some three years ago in a council by-election with 76 per cent of the vote. At the 1983 council elections I was returned from the No. 3 position on the ALP ticket by some 54 votes. Honourable members perhaps can appreciate my keen interest in seeking out those 54 voters. The other suburbs of my electorate are: Blacktown, Prospect, Doonside, Rooty Hill, Minchinbury, Colyton, St Clair and North St Marys. The electorate of Chifley is cosmopolitan and multicultural and is distinguished by the large number of young people and significant numbers of senior citizens. Its distinctive feature is the number of people who have moved or are moving into the electorate.

This is the centenary year of two great Australian Prime Ministers, two great Australians and two great leaders of the Australian Labor Party. I refer, of course, to John Curtin and Ben Chifley. I should like to say a little about Joseph Benedict Chifley. I cannot, of course, claim to have known him. Indeed, at the time of Ben Chifley assuming the prime ministership, I was taking a more substantial form than a gleam in my mother's eye. However, as a young man I read Chifley's biography by Crisp and was deeply impressed by the example provided by Chifley. In this centenary year I fondly hope that some of my younger constituents will similarly be inspired.

In October 1941, Labor assumed office under John Curtin and Chifley became Treasurer. Without a doubt he was Australia's greatest Treasurer, although I suspect that Chifley would demur to Scullin and Theodore. His achievements as Treasurer include the introduction of widow's pensions and unemployment, sickness and hospital benefits. Perhaps his greatest contribution as Treasurer was to marshal the financial resources of Australia to maximise Australia's contribution to the war effort at a time when the conservative parties, the precursors of the Liberal and National parties, had so badly betrayed the trust and faith placed in them.

Chifley was also Minister for Post-war Reconstruction. He became Prime Minister on 13 July 1945, retaining the portfolio of Treasury as well. He led his party to victory in the 1946 election. The achievements of his Government include the beginning of the mass migration scheme and the establishment of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority, Trans-Australia Airlines, the Stevedoring Industry Board and the Joint Coal Board, the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, the nationalisation of Qantas Airways Ltd and overseas telecommunications, and support for Indonesian independence from the Dutch. If I have one misgiving, perhaps those like me who remember 11 November 1975 would rather not have seen proportional voting introduced for the Senate. I congratulate my colleague, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) and the Bathurst City Council on the centenary celebrations they have organised. I sincerely hope that Blacktown and Penrith councils will be able to organise celebrations on a lesser scale.

Until recently, I was proud to be Deputy Mayor of the great city of Blacktown comprising some 200,000 people. I was very proud that Blacktown was the first council in New South Wales to introduce a system for the payment of rates in seven equal instalments. In its first year of operation the system secured a 50 per cent adoption rate, which is proof of its enormous popularity. With great respect, I suggest that the underlying assumptions behind the introduction of the scheme are applicable equally to State and Federal authorities.

I was pleased to be involved in the establishment of the greening of the City of Blacktown committee. I commend the work of that committee and the success it has achieved. Specifically, I mention one project, the Nurragingy Reserve. Indeed, I would be very proud to say that this was my idea. Unfortunately, it was not, However, I can say that I became a very enthusiastic advocate of the project, which captured my imagination. This area of approximately 90 hectares is to be developed as a bicentennial project from funds supplied by Blacktown City Council and both Federal and State governments. The reserve will include 13 individual picnic areas where families can enjoy barbecues and outings, three group picnic areas which can be reserved for the exclusive use of clubs and organisations, natural bushland and an urban forest, artificial lakes, gardens, walking trails, bicycle trails, carparks, public conveniences and maintenance yards. Some $2,182,028 has been allocated to the project with over $1.5m being provided under the Federal Government's community employment program. Some 166 persons have obtained employment on the project.

This Government, Blacktown City Council, the people of Chifley and those who are working on the project can be assured that we are providing a wonderful social asset which will be enjoyed by generations of Australians. I trust that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and Blacktown Council will provide an appropriate opening function.
