The Blacktown City Council, in consultation with the Dharruk Aboriginal Land Council, Blacktown Historical Committee and the Blacktown Bicentenary Committee have officially named the area Nurragingy Reserve after one of Blacktown's best known historical figures. Nurragingy was a member of the local Aboriginal Dharruk tribe and was one of the first Aborigines to receive a land grant in his own right from the colonial government in approximately 1819.

I believe it is appropriate that I should briefly mention the infamous record of the previous Liberal-National Party Government and the record of the first Hawke Labor Government. The Fraser Government was conceived in blood-the blood of the former leader of the Opposition, Sir Billy Snedden-and delivered in a dark cloud of deceit and duplicity which rent asunder long-standing conventions. Whilst continually blaming the Whitlam Government, Fraser and his Liberal-National Party Government presided over an unprecedented period of confrontation, when Australian was pitted against Australian, an unprecedented period of economic stagnation and mismanagement. The rewards went to the privileged few and the brunt was borne by the many, particularly the disadvantaged in our society. Nothing became Malcolm Fraser nor humanised him more than the news of his humiliating defeat. The nation rejoiced.

Bob Hawke had promised national reconstruction and reconciliation. I sincerely believe that if one had taken a poll of Federal parliamentary members of the ALP at the time they would not have predicted the outstanding success achieved on the economic front in a short 21 months in office. Confrontation and division were replaced by consensus. This Hawke Government has consulted widely. It not only governs with the support of the trade union movement but also with that of the business community. The results have been dramatic. Double-digit inflation has been halved. A negative growth economy has been replaced by one of the fastest growing economies of the free world. Banking is being deregulated. The Government is poised to embark on reform of the taxation system. This taxation mess largely has been the legacy of successive Liberal-National Party governments in 30 of the previous 35 years. It is the ordinary men and women of Australia, through the pay-as-you-earn system, who carry an unfair burden of taxation because they do not have the opportunity to minimise their taxation. This reform will be achieved without increasing the overall incidence of taxation. I welcome it and regret that former Liberal-National Party governments continually spoke up about reform but never did anything about it.

We are privileged in Chifley to have many young Australians. I am deeply committed to the concept of equality of opportunity for them and for all Australians. We have many fine schools and facilities in Chifley. However, I do not necessarily believe that this guarantees equality of education. I am dissatisfied with the low participation rates of our students in the last two years of high school. I do not presently have the answers, but I believe the role of teachers is not merely to possess expert knowledge but to have the real ability to reach out to students, to communicate that knowledge and to instil an interest, enthusiasm and understanding for the subject. Teaching is an interesting area. It is the only area where the inputs-the students rather than the teachers-are blamed for the outputs. Nevertheless, I recognise that there are many dedicated teachers in Chifley and I look forward to meeting them and discussing solutions. I am determined to achieve results. It was a pity that the State Government's proposals for a senior high school at Whalan were torpedoed. The John Paul II High School stands as a shining example of what can be achieved in the west.

Equality of opportunity for employment is a major issue within the electorate of Chifley. I take pride in this Government's distinguished record of economic management and job creation, but I am far from satisfied. Unemployment and rising interest rates with their effect on mortgage repayments tear at the social fabric of our community. It is the unemployed who are the victims, not the villains. I have many people in my electorate who are desperately seeking work. I seek jobs, jobs and more jobs for my electorate. I believe that the Federal, State and local governments have an historic opportunity to transform the western suburbs into the industrial heartland of Sydney. I hope to be at the forefront of seizing that opportunity. The Minister for Industry, Commerce and Technology (Senator Button) has, for the first time, sought to heed the numerous reports on manufacturing industry and has started to rationalise and restructure industry. Once again we had the situation, particularly in the 1960s and late 1970s, where the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia in government did absolutely nothing, providing years of wasted opportunity. I have confidence in Australian invention,innovation and the skills of our work force. I believe that government direction and assistance is required to provide growth and more jobs for manufacturing industries. I suspect that neither serendipity nor market forces will generate the growth that we need. We need not only to cut out jobs but also to create them. I look forward to making an input into the Caucus infrastructure committee.

I am an optimist, but even the most optimistic prediction still leaves us a long way short of full employment-indeed, we are unlikely to return to it for some time. It has been rightly said that the accord is central to the Government's management of the economy. In many ways the accord represents what the trade union movement is prepared to forgo for itself for the greater opportunities of the unemployed. I welcome that sacrifice and commitment. However, as a society we must realistically face up the issue of long term unemployment. As I said before, the unemployed are the victims, not the villains. I hope that the Government has the opportunity to review the unemployment benefit with a view to further increasing it. As a society, we need to rethink our attitudes to work. I do not think that the traditional view of a job being 35 or 40 hours a week will survive.

I should like to thank the senior citizens clubs of Mount Druitt, Rooty Hill, Doonside and Blacktown. I was thrilled to be invited to their functions and I appreciated the warmth of their hospitality and friendship. It was, nevertheless, quite disgusting during the election campaign to witness the distress and trauma that these good people suffered as a result of the scare tactics adopted by the Opposition parties when discussing the assets test. These are the people in our community who should be esteemed and supported rather than preyed upon.

I am pleased to have been associated with the Mount Druitt Hospital from its inception and have been pleased to serve as Deputy Chairman of the Board of Directors with His Lordship Bishop Murphy as Chairman. From the outset we have sought to treat the whole person and instil a team approach to the delivery of services. Our most important committee of the board is on patient care review.

I must say that I abhor the current doctors' dispute and was stunned that the Opposition should come out in support of the rebel specialists. What this dispute is all about is: Firstly, money; secondly, who should control the hospital system, be it doctor or state; and, thirdly, whether Medicare patients should have an equality of access to the best medical treatment. I could give many examples, but I shall give only one of where a doctor in surgery halted proceedings on the patient-a child-to ring up the parents from the operating theatre to determine whether the child was privately insured or a Medicare patient.

I am concerned that there are many people in our community who need medical attention but because of the dispute they are not getting it. There are children whose fractures will never be properly set; there are others waiting for the onslaught of another attack, with attendant pain and suffering, so that they may be classified as emergency cases. I regret that the ladies of Our Lady of Consolation Nursing Home and Doonside Nursing Home are being shuffled from one hospital to another. I cannot rule out the possibility that some may have died in the process. The attitude of these rebel specialists is callous and totally indifferent to individual dignity and needs. The whole community condemns them and their advocates, the Liberal Party.

Mr Speaker, I sincerely look forward to the next three years and the opportunity to speak out on behalf of my constituents. I sincerely hope that I will live up to the trust and responsibility placed upon me. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Speaker, for drawing the attention of the House to the fact that this is my maiden speech. At the outset, I thank you, Mr Speaker, and Madam Deputy Speaker for the warm way in which you greeted the new members of this Parliament and for being such gracious hosts during the seminar that we had. As you said, Mr Speaker, I rise for the first time to address members of this Parliament. I am aware of the convention which suggests that a first speech by a member of this House should be heard without interruption. I am conscious of the fact that this is a courtesy that I will probably receive only once in this House. In such circumstances I will refrain from straying, as far as conscience dictates, on to matters which might be considered so political or so sensitive to Government members that they might tempt some to respond through spontaneous reaction. That is not to say that at another time in this same forum I will not seek to draw reaction in the thrust and parry of political debate.

SPEECH.PARA: While speeches in this House may be more savoury with a little salt, I seek today to tempt honourable members' attention, not with spicy oratorical flavour, but rather with the materialistic matters which briefly describe the new Federal division of Hinkler, a few of the problems being faced by constituents and a short resume of that great aviator who has been honoured in that naming.

Hinkler is a provincial and rural coastal electorate in which the main centres of population are situated at Gladstone to the north and Bundaberg to the south. The division stretches from the coast westward across the Dawson River to the boundary of the Duaringa and Banana shires. Prior to redistribution by the electoral Commission, each of three Federal divisions partially serviced the present region. I speak, of course, of Kennedy in the west-represented by my good friend sitting beside me-Capricornia to the north and Wide Bay to the south. The honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) and the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) have continued their service in this House, whilst the former member for Capricornia chose to retire and has been succeeded by another. I thank those past custodians of what is now encompassed in the new Hinkler division for their long and dedicated service to the people now enrolled in the new division. I look forward to co-operation with the three current representatives of Wide Bay, Maranoa and Capricornia in matters of common interest on our boundaries during the term of this Parliament. Whilst one member is not of the same political persuasion, I have known each person for a long time and some affinity has already been established even though, perhaps, in a more relaxed environment. The history of this House bears testimony to the fact that politics are not a barrier to friendship and respect, even though members may be philosophically divided. So should it be at all times.

The Federal division of Hinkler is almost a microcosm of Australia, with a great diversity of economic endeavour and social thinking. The large aluminium processing industries and power house complexes in and near Gladstone have brought a measure of stability to that city. Nevertheless, in the aftermath of massive development, we perceive the difficulties of transition as the itinerant construction and technical workers leave in search of further employment. Small businesses have been closing with demoralising regularity, bringing further unemployment and disruption to families. The social problems we perceive are not unique to Gladstone when we compare the situation with other such growth centres which have slowed down. It is vital for government to recognise, however, that such areas require special consideration and finance to lessen the impact of this demoralising reversal in the economy.

Just a short distance north of Gladstone lie some of the world's richest deposits of oil shale. Demands for this energy resource could escalate sooner than expected if, as aviation indicators suggest, the denser synthetic fuels can provide longer ranges in flight against an equivalent fuel load of fossil derivatives. The city of Bundaberg and the immediate district are also feeling the effects of the recession as the sugar farmers and the dependent industries within that infrastructure face a crisis of serious proportions. Decisions on the future of the sugar industry should place heavier reliance on the short term social problems so created, rather than economic philosophies devoid of compassion. Unfortunately, compassion is not a criterion by any dimension within the academic field of the economist. I remind honourable members that good government is first and foremost a people-orientated institution, and therein lies the purpose of its establishment.

The region around Bundaberg has a viable fruit and vegetable industry which has the capacity to become the salad bowl for South East Asia and other countries. But as the sugar growers turn to these alternative crops to survive, there is a real danger of creating a glut on the domestic market, thus threatening the livelihood of the traditional small crop growers. Support for the continued viability of agricultural production throughout the division will be addressed vigorously by my office during future deliberations in this House. The conventions of this maiden speech preclude such action now, although, Mr Speaker, I am sorely tempted to be more outspoken. However, I ask all honourable members assembled here to recognise the important contribution that primary industry has made to the economy of Australia through vital export income. It is noteworthy, though, to consider that even in these distressing times just one by-product of Bundaberg's sugar production-a little drop probably known to many members of this House; I refer to a famous rum-from one factory contributed over $50m to government revenue by way of excise and sales tax in the last financial year. The income from agricultural production to successive governments has subsidised many projects of benefit to this nation, and the farmers' plea for assistance now should not be so lightly discounted.

The division of Hinkler is also a significant contributor to the economy of Australia through citrus fruits, grains, cotton, beef and other meats, tobacco and dairy products. All these are affected by cost increasing decisions of government. A vigorous export promotion campaign should be maintained with relentless zeal to secure stable markets against the heavily subsidised produce dumped on the international market by the European Community. No members of this House should countenance or support an import parity price philosophy for Australian primary production. Farmers, too, are entitled to a fair day's pay for a fair day's work.

I have read the submissions to the Government by the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation calling for urgent action to restore confidence to the dairy industry. The proposals contained therein have the support of each State organisation. I join them in a call to government to take urgent action to alleviate the financial pressures on the member farmers. Milk is a basic food. The industry has continually argued that holding down dairy product prices could be counterproductive in respect of milk production. Faced with a decline in price, the farmers' first reaction is to increase production in order to maintain gross income and meet commitments. Milk production declines only after the dairy farming community exhausts its capacity to work harder and longer. When this point is reached, farmers leave the industry in great numbers and the resulting decline in production becomes excessive. It should be further noted that the prices of manufactured dairy products in Australia are relatively cheap in comparison with almost all Western countries.

It is true to say that we can purchase many of our agricultural commodities more cheaply today on the international market; but if we allow those primary industries in Australia to be destroyed for consumer orientated expediency, who will guarantee continuity of supply? Who is prepared to guarantee that the price of imports will not increase substantially in the near future? Who will care for the people who have depended on farm income in the many towns the farmers now support? Who indeed? The people on the land have enough to contend with as they battle the elements of nature. Let us not now add indifference of government to the vagaries to which they are exposed.

This nation's wealth and progress emerged from the sweat and tears of primary producers and therein still lies our future. Before we throw in the towel to signify the demise of those rural industries now in serious trouble, let us at least offer a tissue of support and encourage them to go just one more round. They have the will and they have the courage. Let us give them interim financial support.

The known mineral wealth of the Hinkler division is also significant to the economy. Large coal deposits are mined by Thiess Dampier Mitsui Coal Pty Ltd at the Moura and Kianga fields. The old Cracow goldfields are being reworked with new technology and equipment. Many other goldfields are being assessed as the potential to rework the old diggings is improving. Nearer the coast, at Biggenden, one of the few magnetite mines still operates successfully. Additional reserves of oil shale are located at Lowmead and Nagoorin near the coast and at Duaringa in the west. For those who like to go rock-hounding and fossicking, there are many fine gems to be found in the western shire of Banana.

The offshore waters of the Hinkler division also support a large fishing fleet which mainly utilises the facilities for berthing and processing at Gladstone and Bundaberg. The seafood delicacies from these fishing grounds are renowned for the quality and variety of their selection. Yet, the fisherman too face the problems of increasing costs for services and fuels. There are indications also of dwindling stock resources caused by the incursion of large fishing vessels from other centres, and destructive influences affecting traditional fish breeding environments.

The coastal areas and offshore islands in the Hinkler division combined with the historically rich hinterland could be the mecca for increased tourist traffic. There are numerous well-established resorts along the coast and on the islands of the Great Barrier Reef. The many small inland towns offer an old world hospitality which complements the charm of the various localities. Off the beaten track, the adventurous traveller will find breathtaking views of the countryside and many splendid gorges. The residents of Gladstone are justifiably proud of the great natural harbour on which the city nestles and to which they flock for aquatic recreation. Although Port Bundaberg, at the mouth of the Burnett River, is not as well known as the major trading port of Gladstone, it is still a vital sugar, molasses and oil terminal. The Burnett River is also an important recreation facility for the district.

Before concluding, it would be fitting if I were to dwell for a short period to recognise Squadron Leader Bert Hinkler, after whom the Federal division is named. This famous pioneer aviator was small in physical stature, but as Major Turner wrote in the London Daily Telegraph following Bert's tragic death: 'He was a small man with a giant's heart'.

Herbert John Louis Hinkler, affectionately known as Bert, was born in Bundaberg on 8 December 1892. During his pioneer aviation days Bert Hinkler became the idol and hero of all Australians as they proudly sang the praises of Hustling Hinkler, up in the sky.

His principal feats were the first solo flight from Great Britain to Australia and the first solo flight across the South Atlantic Ocean from west to east. His flight across the South Atlantic was an admirable performance, but there is no doubt that the 16-day flight from England to Australia is one of the best remembered. Enduring extreme discomfort in a small Avro Avian, lacking ground and communication support, with primitive navigational aids, and with only an atlas map to guide him, Bert Hinkler displayed courage and determination. The last flight of this great Australian was another solo attempt from England to Australia. Tragically, he lost his life when he crashed in the Prato Magno Alps in Tuscany, Italy, on 8 January 1933. It is a fitting memorial to Bert Hinkler that the new Federal division of Hinkler has been so named.

The holder of the Distinguished Service Medal for bravery in action over Germany in 1916 and the Air Force Cross presented for the finest aerial exploit of 1925, Squadron Leader Bert Hinkler was also presented with the International Aeronautical Federation gold medal in the same year. It is interesting to note that another nominee for the gold medal in the same year was Squadron Leader Charles Kingsford-Smith.

Any person elected to represent the division of Hinkler would be hard-pressed to mirror the feats of this famous man, yet strength can be gained in striving to emulate those personal traits which he displayed. Bert Hinkler was not deterred by the formidable barriers he faced on the way to success. He set a true and faithful course towards his objective, with a determination to succeed against any adversity; fearless in thought, deed and action; believing in what he was doing and the eventual benefit to mankind. Yet Bert Hinkler was constantly humble amidst all the accolades bestowed on him by many nations.

Reference to the life and success of Bert Hinkler surely places a heavy responsibility on this division's representatives to refrain from any action which could demean the name of Hinkler by association. Under such circumstances a representative can only draw strength if he too is not distracted from any course considered true in the navigation of matters political. I am honoured to be known as the member for Hinkler, which I understand, will be the only term used to recognise me in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: In the brief time available to me I would like to draw the attention of honourable members to an article in the Age today, entitled 'An audit of Victoria'. So far as the Cain Government's performance has been under scrutiny in this election, it is largely over the question of tax rises. TALK.START.PARA: —He did that?

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone knows that taxes, fares and charges-

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not the truth. They are not the facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) in congratulating those members of the House who have made their maiden speeches both yesterday and today and commend them on that important milestone in their role as members of the House of Representatives. A number of the maiden speeches, from both sides of the House, have alluded to the fact that among the most disadvantaged in Australia's community today are Australia's primary producers. Australia's primary producers-not because of the unpredictability of nature, which often beleaguers them, but because of falling world markets and the falling Australian economic state-find themselves no longer as profitable as they were. As the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) has so carefully and skilfully explained, a number of Australian primary producers face on average a 17 per cent fall in their annual incomes. We should feed that to the public servants who have been causing this government distress or to the power workers in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I make that point this evening simply because this is the season when primary producers find themselves busiest of all. While we have been in this House talking, people in all our electorates have been carrying out work that is sometimes most unpleasant. I think of those who are on clover harvesters, doing the dusty work of harvesting small seeds; I think of those who are without any shade at all in grape patches harvesting grapes; I think of those who, in the itch of a peach patch, are currently harvesting clingstone peaches, in spite of the itch and fluff that is implicit in that work. The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest) has already alluded to the importance of hard work, and I rose this evening because I was astonished to see in yesterday's Australian an article that said:
New South Wales and Victorian-
note 'Victorian'-
fruit growers are facing an employment crisis. They cannot find enough pickers to harvest their pears, peaches and grapes.

Should a nation with the unemployment statistics of this nation carry an article like that in its leading daily? What sort of reflection is it on the Australian nation when we have work to be done and people who are unemployed, but growers are unable to find people from that unemployment pool to do the work that needs to be done. It is absurd to find that article in the Australian and then to find attached to a press release from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) a comment that he is planning to spend $24,571 to create four jobs for 16 weeks to expand a community vegetable garden. A little further down it is said that he is planning to spend in the Lockhart River community $23,071 to create four jobs for 16 weeks to expand another community vegetable garden. All this is happening while the fruit growers of Victoria are unable to find people to pick their temporarily profitable crops. It would be the height of irony if we were to discover that the unemployed in Australia were not prepared to harvest the crops we need harvested while the Asian people, with their green revolution, are becoming increasingly productive, achieving grain production levels we scarcely dare to hope are possible, and are employing people who were once unemployed. It is in the interests of the fruit growers of South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria that I make this plea.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, Madam Deputy Speaker, I congratulate you on once again achieving election to your high office. At the start of this adjournment debate I listened with some interest to the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) quoting extensively from an article in today's Age. The figures referred to by Mr Cain, as reported by the Age, which were calculated by the Liberal Party, indicate a 29 per cent increase in per capita taxes under the Liberals and an 8 per cent increase under Labor. I wholeheartedly endorse the terms of that article. It shows the economic illiteracy of the Victorian Branch of the Liberal Party for it to use the CPI index as an all-encompassing economic measure. As the article points out, the appropriate measure to be used in the context in which the Liberal Party wished to use it was the implicit price deflator. If one is to enter into economic debate it is important to get the fundamentals of the debate correct. As I have said, to use the CPI is simply an indicator of economic illiteracy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Cain Labor Government has a strong record of performance over the last three years but, more importantly, it has a program for the next 10 years. For the first time in the post-war period an Australian government has put down a concise and well thought out program. This program maximises the relative advantages that the Victorian economy has over other State governments and, more particularly, over our overseas competitors. The 10-year program set down--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —This may be boring to those members of the Opposition who are not interested in economics. Perhaps I should mention some of Mr Kennett's statements, such as whether one would allow one's daughter to go out with the Premier of Victoria-a juvenile and stupid statement. Another related to working out the difference between adult wages and award wages. Clearly he was unable to do so when he promulgated the so-called YES scheme, a scheme I might add, that has been universally condemned by most observers and by almost all young people to whom I have spoken. SPEECH.PARA: I come back to what is important in the election campaign-plans for the future of Victoria and of its economy. The Victorian Government, as I have indicated, has laid down a 10-year program to maximise the relative advantage that Victoria has over its competitors. It is all fairly complicated stuff, but I would commend the reading of that program to honourable members opposite because it is much better than coming up with advertising jargon or gimmicks in an attempt to hoodwink the Victorian electors. For example, the program sets out some major areas that Victoria will concentrate on in the next 10 years. It looks at the extent and diversity of Victoria's industrial skill base, something that simply was not addressed under previous governments. The program looks at the development of Melbourne as an industrial and international commercial centre. It looks at the location of the Port Phillip region as a major component in transport, distribution and communications for the south-eastern part of Australia.

I could go on, but my time is limited. Suffice it to say that when one is faced with a choice between two parties, both promulgating their platforms, it is important to look a little further than the nearest advertising gimmick that one can come up with. It is my submission, and I am sure it is supported by most Victorians, that the present Government in Victoria has done a great deal over the last three years and, given the chance, it will be in a position in the next three years to reap some significant rewards for the Victorian economy and to try to set about achieving reasonable rates of employment and growth in the Victorian economy.
